0800103661|5.0|Gattaca is a fascinating science fiction/mystery movie, set in the 'not too distant future', in which astronauts dress in stylish, roaring-twenties inspired clothing and where the world seems to be finely ordered and sequenced, just like a genetic code.<br />In fact, it is the genetic code which determines all. Test-tube babies are the norm for anyone who wants to have a chance; screening out imperfections has become routine, and those who have the misfortune of being born outside the system of genetic checks and balances will find themselves invalid (in-valid in the sense of not valid for work, as well as invalid in the sense of incapacitated for advancement). Society has been structured around a pre-defined sense of potential as projected by genetic codes. But there are a few who challenge the system.<br />Meet Vincent, a.k.a. Jerome Morrow (played by Ethan Hawke), who dreams of the stars and lusts for a position at Gattaca (the new-age NASA), but with the genetic code of a loser. Enter Jerome Morrow, a.k.a. Eugene (played by Jude Law), who has the potential, but also a broken spinal cord -- he lends Vincent, through an ingenious and intricate system, his genetic sequence. In this guise, Vincent thus rises to the position of navigator, selected for the great Titan/Saturn mission.<br />Then, the director gets murdered. A flake of skin falls from Vincent which the investigators find, and the chase is on. The launch is a week away. Will Vincent outrun the pursuers in time?<br />Of course, Vincent's pursuers are led by his brother, the genetically-planned offspring of the family, who thought that Vincent was dead. There is an ultimate contest, which Vincent wins, proving the victory of determination over pre-determination.<br />Vincent, in the person of Jerome, falls in love with Irene (played by Uma Thurman), who works at Gattaca in a sort of genetic quality-control position. She falls in love the potential, the idea of Jerome, but eventually comes to love the imperfect Vincent. She herself, for all the genetic planning, also has an imperfection, which makes her all the more attractive to Vincent.<br />Gore Vidal has a small but crucial role as a flight director in charge of keeping things on track (with style!) as the murder investigation threatens the operations at Gattaca.<br />This movie is a visually interesting, unique, and much under-rated and under appreciated show. It won awards for art direction and other stylistic touches, including the Oscar.<br />I won't spoil the ending, but suffice it to say that Vincent and Jerome both leave the earth.<br />'For someone never meant for this world, I must confess, I'm suddenly having a hard time leaving it. Of course, they say that every atom of our body was once part of a star. Maybe I'm not leaving. Maybe I'm going home.'<br />Interestingly, the idea of genetics is woven into the movie in very many ways, some subtle, some explicit. The very title, Gattaca, consists of the strands of bases that comprise the double helix of DNA G (guanine), A (adenine), C (cytosine), and T (thymine) -- the sequence of these bases constitutes genetic information, much as the arrangement of the 26 letters of this alphabet constitutes information.<br />This is a clever film, a bit slow, but stylish, suspenseful, wonderfully visual, and well worth a weekend evening investment.ect Vincent. She herself, for all the genetic planning, also has an imperfection, which makes her all the more attractive to Vincent.<br />Gore Vidal has a small but crucial role as a flight director in charge of keeping things on track (with style!) as the murder investigation threatens the operations at Gattaca.<br />This movie is a visually interesting, unique, and much under-rated and under appreciated show. It won awards for art direction and other stylistic touches, including the Oscar. <br />I won't spoil the ending, but suffice it to say that Vincent and Jerome both leave the earth.<br />'For someone never meant for this world, I must confess, I'm suddenly having a hard time leaving it. Of course, they say that every atom of our body was once part of a star. Maybe I'm not leaving. Maybe I'm going home.'<br />Interestingly, the idea of genetics is woven into the movie in very many ways, some subtle, some explicit. The very title, Gattaca, consists of the strands of bases that comprise the double helix of DNA G (guanine), A (adenine), C (cytosine), and T (thymine) -- the sequence of these bases constitutes genetic information, much as the arrangement of the 26 letters of this alphabet constitutes information.<br />This is a clever film, a bit slow, but stylish, suspenseful, wonderfully visual, and well worth a weekend evening investment.

B00008PC2O|5.0|Well, people have nearly said it all about this new DVD edition.  But I just wanted to add a few things:  The version in this Extreme DVD, is the \\"Special Extended edition\\". Despite what it says on the menu, it is not the plain special edition. It actually includes all the possible deleted escenes they ever took out (t-1000 scanning john's room and the alternative ending are accesible via watching the movie on \\"interactive mode\\").  And some people are saying that the only way to see the theatrical version is by playing the disc on your computer's DVD-ROM, on windows media 9 series. Well, that is not true. You can watch the theatrical version on your normal DVD player. Just highlight (red) \\"sensory control\\", then on your remote control press the \\"right\\" button 5 times. To the right, the phrase \\"The future is not set\\" will appear. Then press \\"enter\\" on your remote control, and the \\"play special edition\\" will morph into \\"theatrical version\\". There you have it.

B00009TB5G|5.0|The quest continues to destroy Sauron's ring in this remarkable sequel in the Lord of the Rings trilogy.  The Two Towers manages to retain the same amount of characterization, story development, and theatrical style that made the first film so powerful and amazing.<br />The film's characters are still remarkably well-developed.  Their relationships flourish and grow more complicated, as Frodo becomes more corrupt and Gollum reveals a split personality (which is shown extremely well in the film!).  There's also more humor among the existing characters.<br />Surprisingly, supporting characters rarely seen in the original book are also further developed (Arwen, Elrond, and Celeborn make a reappearance).  And new characters also recieve a fair amount of development.  The only bad thing about the characters is that Saruman doesn't make much of an appearance.<br />The film retains the same visual style as the last film.  There's more large-scale shots, particuarly as the armies of Mordor are seen marching across the land.  It's breathtaking to see thousands and thousands of orcs marching across the screen; there's no other film like it.  The battle of Helm's Deep is equally remarkable and is the highlight of the whole film.  Also noteworthy are the ents, who ultimately sack Isengard.  Even the ruined city where the Nazgul rule was done well.  Among all these great scenes, there's still some artistic elements as well that embellish the story's ideas.<br />There are certain elements that the film has incorporated that were not present in the original story, such as the elves' involvement in Helm's Deep, or Aragorn's battle with the orc wolf-riders.  These added elements may take away from the accuracy of the movie, but are still enjoyable to watch.<br />This movie serves as a fine chapter in the whole trilogy.  It's just as good as the last film and is very much worthy of watching.

Technically speaking, tATu's debut album is your run of the mill teenage pop album. Of course what makes them different from the likes of Christina Aguilera, Britney Spears, Mandy Moore and the likes is that they have a distinct European flavor to them. Whether that should be a repellent or attraction, is certainly up to you.<br />The negative aspects often get overshadowed by those who enjoy the album very much. However, let's be realistic here. The lyrics are repetitive, music is synthesized, the vocals are high and almost close screaming, yet what makes this so special? That leads us to the positive aspects.<br />tATu's debut album is full of energy and of course, it's wonderful to hear something different in America. While many of the radio stations are overwhelmed with R&amp;B tracks or pop R&amp;B or punk, metal, rock and the likes, tATu provides us with some European pop. With the overplayed track 'All The Things She Said' being the lead single to the soft and 'Russian-sounding' piano track '30 minutes' to the techno inspired 'Not Gonna Get Us.' This album basically covers several genres while blending them into one genre that we could call 'Techno/ Electronica Pop.' <br />Overall, if you're looking for a wonderful composed masterpiece, look somewhere else. However, if you enjoy pop albums and don't really care about the gimmick, then I say this album is for you. First listen to the sound clips, if you like them, chances are you'll enjoy the rest of the album. After all it's only 11 tracks.<br />The Cd comes enhanced with a interview with tATu and music video for 'All The Things She Said.' A nice bonus, but perhaps the album is a little meager in tracks.

B000002UVX|5.0|For anyone who believes Hendrix was over-rated, listen to this! The guitar work on this album is extraordinary and there are no studio effects to enhance it. <br />New Years Eve 1969/1970, Hendrix teamed up with Buddy Miles and Billy Cox to perform soulful rock with a message. A message of love. From the funky opening riff of \\"Who Knows?\\", the listener knows immediately that Hendrix has changed direction. The music is full of soul and as we go on through the disc, we find it is also full of love.<br />The anti-war statement of Machine Gun is possibly one of the most historic live rock and roll moments next to Dylan's '66 Albert Hall retaliation and Jimi's own Star Spangled Banner performance. Using the instruments as weapons, the musicians create a vivid image of the horrors of Vietnam. <br />The song Message of Love is also incredible and perfectly demonstrates the chemistry between the power-trio. All three, even while playing separate rhythms, sound like they are all in unison.<br />But the thing that stands out the most is the guitar. The sounds Hendrix creates are out of this world. He was at his peak and it is a real shame that he died shortly after this recording. There's no telling where he could have taken music.

B00008LDPU|5.0|To anyone who is familiar with Anime, or Japanimation, the Japanese influences on the makers of the Matrix should be clear. The energy and style of the action scenes in this sci-fi modern classic are borrowed directly from the classic Anime features of the 80s and 90s like Ghost In The Shell, Akira and Ninja Scroll. What we see in Animatrix is a fascinating project: The best directors and animators in Japanime were approached by the Wachowski Bros. to create short animated stories taking place in the reality of the Matrix saga. The result: nine short films by seven different directors. Each of the creators took the ideas that make the Matrix to entirely different ends, and each film uses different styles and techniques of animation and storytelling. Not one of them is traditional Japanese animation, and though each one borrows from its old and respectable roots, each one is surprising and unique in a very different way. That makes this compilation of the nine films a very rewarding watching experience, if you're interested in either the Matrix or animation in general, or both.<br />The first segment, The Final Flight Of The Osiris, is a direct prequel to Matrix Reloaded, though it features none of the lead characrers from the movies. It's my least favorite movie in the series, but makes for a good start to the collection. The animation here is entirely computerized 3D graphics, and as technology goes it's the most impressive film in the series.<br />The two part movie The Second Renaissance (directed by Mahiro Maeda) looks more like traditional anime. It's essential for eager Matrix fans, because it chronicles the Second Renaissance and man's war against the machines - events that were only referred to in the movie Matrix. It's a fascinating watch, more for the story than for the animation.<br />Kid's Story (directed by the brilliant Shinichirô Watanabe of Cowboy Bebop fame) is the first movie here that really caught my attention. A rather small story about one ofthe many people who realized the truth about the Matrix and were freed to reality (with Keanu Reeves and Carrie-Anne Moss doing small cameos), the animation on Kid's Story is as far as you can get from any kind of traditional animation, Japanese or otherwise. It's energetic, powerful, and hypnotically beautiful.<br />The World Records was created by Takeshi Koike (director) and Yoshiaki Kawajiri (writer), the immensely talented team that worked together on the cult classic Ninja Scroll. Koike's very unique art style comes on strongly on this segment, with his deformed characters, exaggerated motion and expression and very strong shadowing, and the characters' motion is strong and beautiful.<br />The Program, directed by Kawajiri himself, is relatively closer to classic anime, but it's well written and has good energy. Not one of my favorites, though.<br />A Detective Story was both written and directed by Shinichirô Watanabe. Unlike his other work, Kid's Story, a Detective Story greatly resembles his work on Cowboy Bebop. It blends the atmosphere and clichés of classic film noir into the Matrix reality, and has great writing and animation. The art is in black on white, with a great gritty texture that gives it a real film noir feel.<br />Beyond is a rather small story about children in Japan who find a `haunted house', where objects appear and disappear, and people can float in the air and defy the rules of nature - actually, of course it's just a glitch in the Matrix and the Agents are soon sent to remedy the situation. The long scene of the children playing in the haunted house is beautiful and imaginative, and wonderfully animated.<br />Matriculated, the final segment, is a very difficult and disturbing one, and I didn't really care for the choice of putting it last in the series. Psychedelic and very philosophical, Matriculated is shown mainly from a machine's point of view.<br />The bonus features on the DVD are also fantastic: they include fascinating documentaries on all each film, and also on the project in general and on the history and tradition of Japanese animation. For animation enthusiasts, this DVD is a must.
B000089RVX|5.0|I'm sure we've all fallen (no pun intended) in love with the 'Bring Me To Life' single that's playing on the radio. I did, and immediately rushed out to buy this album, not expecting any of the tracks to even sound remotely like it (the fate of many records nowdays).<br />Imagine my surprise when I found such a lovely gem! Evanescence has burst out of the woodworks, and I hope they're here to stay. They mix a wonderful sound of hard guitars and synth, and soft, soaring, wistful vocals provided by Amy Lee. If you're trying to figure out what they sound like, cross Garbage with Linkin Park and throw some romantic fantasy in there. What you get is not quite goth, not quite metal, not quite girl-rock that seems to blend effortlessly and create an amazing listen.<br />'Going Under' is the first track on the album, and the next single, and it's very catchy.  Amy's voice growls and then soars, and I find myself humming this song all day long.<br />'Bring Me To Life' is the same as the classic on the radio, and I'm very glad they left Paul (from 12 Stone) on the track -- so often bands take their 'guest' off the actual record and the song suffers.<br />'Everybody's Fool'--A weaker track with a gutsy message, about how pretending to be something you aren't doesn't fool anyone.<br />'My Immortal' -- the most haunting track on the album, and a personal favorite of mine. It's so simple and pure that it seems a-cappella and almost out of place, but I like the nice change from the driving rock to the sentimental side.<br />'Haunted' and 'Tourniquet' are great rock songs, and a good choice for the middle of the album. While some folks have mistaken 'Tourniquet' for a Christian song, I don't really think that is the case -- it's more of a song about suicide, and wondering what is on the other side.<br />'Imaginary' is a delight, with lyrics a day-dreamer would love about a fantasy world, and not wanting to wake up from dreams. I absolutely love this song. It's such a fun, fantastical side to them that one rarely sees in rock nowdays (save for perhaps Linkin Park videos).<br />'Taking Over Me' and 'Hello' aren't two of my favorite tracks, but they're still easy to listen to and fit seamlessly with the album. 'Hello' is another slow song.<br />My favorite songs on the album are the next two -- 'My Last Breath' and 'Whisper'. They're powerful, haunting, and somehow manage to sound unique in comparison to the rest of the album. I love them!<br />Enough with the gushing. If you're thinking about Evanescence and buying the album because you like 'Bring Me To Life' but are afraid that it will be the only great, rock-driven song on the album, don't worry! You'll love it. Also, if you're worried that it's too 'goth' or too 'christian', don't worry about that either. Evanescence toes the line between several genres and manages to find a sound entirely their own.ical side to them that one rarely sees in rock nowdays (save for perhaps Linkin Park videos).<br />'Taking Over Me' and 'Hello' aren't two of my favorite tracks, but they're still easy to listen to and fit seamlessly with the album. 'Hello' is another slow song. <br />My favorite songs on the album are the next two -- 'My Last Breath' and 'Whisper'. They're powerful, haunting, and somehow manage to sound unique in comparison to the rest of the album. I love them!<br />Enough with the gushing. If you're thinking about Evanescence and buying the album because you like 'Bring Me To Life' but are afraid that it will be the only great, rock-driven song on the album, don't worry! You'll love it. Also, if you're worried that it's too 'goth' or too 'christian', don't worry about that either. Evanescence toes the line between several genres and manages to find a sound entirely their own.

B000099T2L|3.0|I never wanted to do this, but I feel compelled to give Beyonce Knowles some credit.  A few years back, we gave her hell for being the stuck-up princess in Destiny's Child, but she ignored the haters and smartly turned herself into a one-lady institution.  Burning the candle at both ends under a tight schedule, Beyonce has done modeling, acting, and now she's finally released the solo album we all knew was coming: \\"Dangerously in Love.\\"  The album is sporadically successful in presenting a mature Knowles, but the material doesn't always deliver on its promise to be a powerhouse r&b record.  The disc falters mainly on the uptempo tunes, many of which just don't kick.  \\"Naughty Girl\\" falls flat even as it borrows the groove from Donna Summer's \\"Love to Love You Baby;\\" \\"Baby Boy\\" is dumbed-down dancehall fluff featuring reggae flavor du jour Sean Paul, and \\"Hip Hop Star\\" with Sleepy Brown and Big Boi lacks both the hip and hop to make it remotely danceable.  \\"Dangerously in Love\\" improves on the ballads which make the best use of Beyonce's voice.  You can't say \\"no\\" to the seductive groove of \\"Yes\\" while Missy Elliott guests on the solid \\"Signs.\\"  And she shows that she can hold her own against an r&b veteran like Luther Vandross on their cover of \\"The Closer I Get to You.\\"  But the album's best track is \\"Speechless,\\" a slow jam inspired by the old school that's so smokin' it almost saves the rest of the album.  \\"Dangerously in Love\\" is ultimately spotty and weighed down by too many subpar tracks, but there's enough material to prove that she does have potential when paired with the right collaborators (she co-produced much of the album herself).  On a scale of 1 to 10, I'd give it a 6.

Wether this of the seminal original is the best is debatable, but what is for sure is that it is truly one awesome thrill ride packed with out-of-this world effects that still amaze 11 years later. Will the upcoming Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines be better? Only time will tell, but rest assured, T2 takes it deserved place in the collection of all-time greats and is a must-have on DVD.

B00008H2LB|5.0|First off, let's get some things straight. Linkin Park are NOT heavy/thrash/death metal. They've never claimed to be and most certainly do not make music that would fit into any of those categories. <br />Therefore, Meteroa is not an album that can be classfied in any of the above genres. What Meteora is however, is an excellent fusion of rock, hip hop, eletronica with undercurrents of true pop running beneath it all. It's a heady mix, much like the record's illustrious predecessory, Hybrid Theory. Meteora takes the best parts of Hybrid Theory and magnifys them plentyfold. It's a maturer, more tunefulbut harder rocking Linkin Park that appears on this album. The songs are tight and quick, there are no fillers here. Each and every song has a point and provides a link from the preceding song to the forthcoming one. The whole band sounds tighter and more attuned to each other, the vocalists blend and meld together with astonishing ease, and yet maintain their individual styles without outshining the other. No one part overcomes the other, the guitars are superbly complemented by the bass, the drumming mixes excellently with the DJ's scratching, which in turn provides an edge for the vocalists to take and shape into their own special style. Not one strand of music is wasted and the sheer musicianship that is present in Meteora really should be applauded. I'm tired of being taken for a ride by bands who think that two good songs on album will automatically negate ten other songs that sound awful, with no thought or care going into the recording or mixing. Who cares about guitar solos and the like when you can listen to songs that are not only intricately layered but also so individually and thus collectively complete?<br />This album isn't the most revolutionary, nor does it claim to be. It's a band doing what they do best, trailing a blazing path through which their contemporaries must either adher to or wither away when the inevitable comparisons begin. What it is is astatement of intent: that Linin Park are here to stay. And thank God for that.

B00009V7T2|5.0|I bought the best album of the year yesterday. 'De-loused in the comatorium'. In case you've had your head under a rock for the past few months, it's the debut album by The Mars Volta, and incase you're a Britney Spears fan you'll probably know that The Mars Volta consists of Omar Rodriguez and Cedric Bixler who were partly, if not mostly responible for one of the most amazing and important rock bands of recent times (at the drive-in, duh!). <br />I've been waiting for this record ever since they gave us that tasty three song EP. Boy have they kept us waiting, but damn me if it wasn't worth the wait! I knew this album was going to be amazing when I saw TMV live, but I had absoultely no idea it was going to be THIS damn mindblowing. I walked three miles into town and 3 miles back to pick up this album. It was burning a hole in my pocket all the way home, it was like an orgasm when I finally got it out of the case and put it into my stereo while looking through the artwork. Then I laid back in bed, closed my eyes and let the my mind get lost in this music. It just took me over, it's so amazing. It's a concept album, about a close friend of Omar and Cedric who was in a coma for a long time. It basically follows this guy in a coma as he travels through some bizzare, subconscious world. Now I know all of this makes this record sound terrible. By the rules of EVERYTHING prog rock and concept albums usually make for horrible listening, unless it's pink floyd, in which case, we'll let you off. We'll also let The Mars Volta off too, because no matter how pretentious the whole concept of this album sounds, no matter how much you're expecting capes and 30 minute organ solos, once you listen to this album you forget all about that shit. This is Prog with punk rock ideals. The music is convicted with so much aggression, energy and verve that it's hard not to get completely and utterly lost in it. The band continually barrage you with extremely loud, disjointed guitar riffs, skull shattering bass, and pyschotic keyboards. This is topped off with effects and sound manipulation by Jeremy Ward, who sadly recently lost his life. His influence can be heard allover this record, which would undoubtley be half the album it is without his work, which makes it all the more potent. All of this fits perfectly with Cedric's vocals, which go from gentle crooning and verge upon screaming falsetto.<br />The musicians occasionally break down into free form jams which incorporate jazz, blues, funk, dub, punk and a thousand other musical influences (ok maybe not a thousand, but you get the picture). Despite all of this, it's still very much a rock record, and no matter how challenging it sometimes gets this record still has a great sense of melody. It's by no means a mainstream album, and it wont be for everyone but it has enough hooks to keep you drawn in, and sometimes make you shake your ass. This record does what all truely groundbreaking records do, it challenges, it experiments, it attempts to revolutionize rock all while never really alienating the person listening to it. This is what makes albums like 'Sgt Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band', 'Pet Sounds' 'Marquee Moon', 'OK Computer' such awe inspiring and influential pieces of music. I truely Believe that 'De-Loused in The Comatorium' will be remembered alongside such records.<br />It's a truely unbelievably amazing piece of music. From the beginning keyboard arpeggio and haunting organ of first track 'Son Et Lumiere' to the final breakdown of 'Take The Veil Cerpin Taxt' it never lets off, it's a musical journey which once it's over you have to stop and try and make sense of everything that just happened, then play it over again. I know it's a cliche to say so, but this really is an album that has to be heard for yourself. So go out and buy it. Nothing can stop The Mars Volta now.

B00009V7T2|5.0|Hypnotic patterns draw you in and lead through a musical labrynth. This album is as much visual as it is auditory. De-Loused in the Comatorium is a concept album set around the trials of one Cerpain Taxt. In Taxt's attempt to commit suicide, he falls into a coma for a time and this is where the album beings. Taxt is thrown into a world (via his comatic stuper) completely different from our own yet symbolically congruent. His journey through this world leads him on an almost reverse initiation which is represented to us in the form of music. The songs are pact with so much intensity that the listener almost becomes Cerpain Taxt. Omar Rodriguez-Lopez and Cedric Bixler Zavala (the founders and conceptual inovators of the album) have made an album that is almost arrogant it's so good. Rodriguez-Lopez's guitar playing is very angular and rythmic, and in my opinion probably the driving force behind the music. Zavala's has a surisingly wide vocal range. I mean he almost sounds like Freddy Mercury, but much more serious...of course, no leather chaps here. The keyboards, amazing percussion, and a little help from Flea, of Red Hot Chili Pepers fame, ties everything together incredibly well. EVERYONE in this band does their part to their fullest ability and it has really shown. This stuff is up there with Sonic Youth and Pink Floyd. I think I'm just so excited to hear people this incredibly serious and passionate about music and creating music with meaning that I can't say enough. Just buy this for your own good...seriously. Yeah, I'll shut up now.

0783222955|5.0|'To Kill a Mockingbird' the only written Pulitzer Prize classic by Harper Lee to gain so much in literary or film history. It has become not only a tale of a single father's love for his two children but a social commentary of socialism, racism and injustice. Director Robert Mulligan delivers Lee's classic with such precision that the book translation into the film reatined it's quality with nothing lost. What other films taken from books can say that? It has made the American Film Institute's (AFI) list of top 100 films of all time. It's considered one of the finest examples of family drama ever made. Even though set in a 1932 Depression-era Southern town of Maycomb, Alabama, in history it still remains timeless. It's message still remains powerfully strong and resounding in our American society today. It still defends the cause of tolerance, justice, sound morals and responsible, loving single parenthood.<br /><br />This message is just as very much important today as it was then. I recommend this to people of all ages. The courtroom drama is beyond mundane or formality. Gregory Peck is Atticus Finch, small-town Alabama lawyer and widower father of two. This is one of his best performances that got him the Oscar at the Academy Awards in 1962. He takes on with compassion the defense of a black man (Brock Peters) accused of rape and murder of a young white woman. His children Scout (Mary Badham) who tells the story and her brother Jem (Philip Alford) learn about racial prejudice and hatred. They also overcome their fear of a mysterious, obscure and silent neighbor Boo Radley (Robert Duvall, in his brilliant screen debut). Some of the best classic lines from the movie when Atticus has a quiet moment with his children. If you just learn a single trick, Scout, you'll get along a lot better with all kinds of folks. You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view...Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it. And he tells them about it was a sin to kill a mockingbird. The mockingbird was different from all the other birds...because mockingbirds don't do anything but make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat people's gardens, don't nest in the corncrib, they don't do one thing but just sing their hearts out for us.<br /><br />What comes from this beautifully told film is a shining, intense drama that cleverly extracts the ideas of Harper Lee's heartfelt classic, a tremendously talented group of American actors brought together in one film and the magic of devoted artistry of screenplay and an outstanding score. It's strength has survived all the madness and complexity of today's so-called Hollywood cinema. 'To Kill a Mockingbird' is truly an all-time classic that speaks for itself.ells them about it was a sin to kill a mockingbird. The mockingbird was different from all the other birds...because mockingbirds don't do anything but make music for us to enjoy. 0375422307|5.0|Never before have I read a graphic novel that moved me through so many emotions in such a short amount of time. Satrapi writes about and draws her adolescence in Iran during the country's periods of the revolution and war. She also allows us to see how she was feeling at those times (mostly, it seems, she was feeling rebellious).<br />She tells us what it's like for females to suddenly be forced to wear a veil when outside their homes. She covers some of her own amazing family history (her great-grandfather was Iran's last emperor). She also talks of Iran's war with Iraq in the early 80's and it's only too relevant to our current events. What's more, she's funny. Watching &quot;Marji&quot; as a little girl in the book, re-acting to situations as only a little girl would, you're able to sympathize, if not empathize.<br />I saw Satrapi speak at this year's Book Expo America and I walked away with a with a feeling that this woman is part artist, part rebel, part humanitarian and part historian. She's also very very funny. When asked whether or not she's want a movie based on her memoir, she said [heavy French accent], &quot;No, I don't think so. I think they would make it too much like 'Never Without my Daughter'.&quot; Right now, she's working on a sequel to Persepolis.<br />You should read this.

B00005JMC6|4.0|WHALE RIDER comes from New Zealand, and opens with a Maori mother giving birth to twins, a son and a daughter. Unfortunately, the mother and son die in the delivery room. The father, Porourangi (Cliff Curtis), is left with only his infant daughter, Pai.<br />A dozen years later, Pai (Keisha Castle-Hughes) lives in a Maori seashore community with her grandparents, Koro (Rawiri Paratene) and Nanny Flowers (Vicky Haughton). Koro is the tribal leader, the direct descendent of the original leader who, according to legend, came with his people from a faraway place on the backs of whales. Koro and hoped that his eldest son, Porourangi, would become chief, but the latter, after the death of his wife and son, left for Europe to become an artist. Koro is devastated by the loss of his male descendents. Though he loves Pai dearly, he consciously and deliberately excludes her from consideration as his successor. She is, after all, but a girl. So, Koro must select another heir apparent from the community after weeding out the teenage, male candidates. Pai is crushed; she loves her grandfather, and feels she must make up for the loss of her brother. Besides, she knows she's up to the job.<br />I liked WHALE RIDER - up to a point. It incorporates so many of those social and personal struggles that make a good touchy-feely tear jerker: generation gap (Koro vs. Porourangi), gender bias (Koro vs. Pai), and coming-of-age (Pai vs. herself). Paratene as Koro is alternately likable and hateful as the amiable grandfather/stern traditionalist who doesn't have a clue. Haughton is a most pleasant surprise as Nanny Flowers, Pai's ally and Koro's chief critic. As Nanny puts it to her husband one night during a period of domestic tension, he may be the boss outside, but in their home she's in charge (and he'd better not forget it!). Castle-Hughes is winning as the plucky Pai.<br />I won't award five stars because I left the screening feeling overtly manipulated. Whales have a significant part in this film, and indeed catalyze the outcome of Pai's struggle for recognition. And everybody is supposed think whales warm and cuddly, right? Also, the film's focus on a society so different from that of American audiences will perhaps arouse in the viewers a self-satisfying sense of politically correct, cultural sensitivity. I've had it up to here with the concept of political correctness. And the circumstances of Pai's triumph transcended plausible reality just a wee bit.<br />Finally, I was left fidgety with the nagging feeling that the Maori teenage boys being tutored by Koro would have been better off learning, say, computer skills, rather than traditional chants or how to fight with big sticks. At the end of the day, successfully recovering the chief's whale's-tooth amulet from the sea bottom is unlikely to get you off the reservation, so to speak. Indeed, the only major character who's coping with the larger world, Porourangi, comes across as diminished by the attempt. I'm doubt that's the right message for any culture.this film, and indeed catalyze the outcome of Pai's struggle for recognition. And everybody is supposed think whales warm and cuddly, right? Also, the film's focus on a society so different from that of American audiences will perhaps arouse in the viewers a self-satisfying sense of politically correct, cultural sensitivity. I've had it up to here with the concept of political correctness. And the circumstances of Pai's triumph transcended plausible reality just a wee bit. <br />Finally, I was left fidgety with the nagging feeling that the Maori teenage boys being tutored by Koro would have been better off learning, say, computer skills, rather than traditional chants or how to fight with big sticks. At the end of the day, successfully recovering the chief's whale's-tooth amulet from the sea bottom is unlikely to get you off the reservation, so to speak. Indeed, the only major character who's coping with the larger world, Porourangi, comes across as diminished by the attempt. I'm doubt that's the right message for any culture.

B00004SZWB|4.0|After the brilliant,yet bewildered &quot;Journey Through The Secret Life Of Plants&quot;,Stevie rushed out(by his standards) with Hotter Than July,the true follow-up to Songs In The Key Of Life.The fact that it isn't up to the standards of the Talking Book or Innervisions is already a constant,but it brings a closure to a winning streak of albums that began with 1972's Music Of My Mind(or 71's Where I'm Coming From according to true Stevie fans).Every cut is a stand-out especially Master Blaster,All I Do,I Ain't Gonna Stand For It(a country tinged tune worthy of a Garth Brooks cover),and the much interpretated classic Lately.The final cut,the MLK-tribute Happy Birthday brings the album to a glorious open-ended finish as well as beautifully closes the book on this Wonder-ful chapter of his career.
B0000041Q3|5.0|This is one of the best selling opera recording of our time. The three principles are the biggest superstars in opera. Since it's generally universally regarded that Pavarotti and Caballe are the best in their roles, I'll concentrate on Joan Sutherland here. Whom although a vast majority of opera fans  agreed was brilliant here,  a tiny minority but vocal  Nilsson fans feel that the Swedish Wagnerian soprano was the ideal Turandot. Let me tell you why I think Sutherland is a better Principessa of Ice than Birgit Nilsson.<br />There are those who criticize Joan Sutherland for having the lack of size for the formidible role of Turandot. The truth is, she was originally trained to be a Wagnerian dramatic soprano. In the middle 1950's She could have sang Brunhilda  if she chose to. In fact, she did sing Eva in Wagner's Meistersinger with great success early in her career. The quality of her high notes are legendary. If you were in the audience of a 1961 Lucia with Sutherland at the Met, her high E flats were rockets that almost blew up the place. They were the among the largest high notes I've ever heard. As an old timer opera fan, I can honestly tell you Sutherland's highest  notes from her youth were even larger than Nilsson's, especially the notes above high C. And that's from a fan who's heard them both numerous times. However, her midrange was never as strong as the Swedish diva. And her lower range can't be compare to Nilsson's. But remember, the recording studio can even that up.<br />True, in this Turandot, Sutherland is 10 years older than when I first heard her as Lucia in 1961. This recording is 1971. The diva's voice is much darker, and her upper register has lost some of it's power. This to be compare to Nilsson's 1960 recording is nonsense. Of course Nilsson had more power in 1960 than Sutherland in 1971, but what's the point? Both have more than enough juice to sing the confused princess. And whoever said that Sutherland's voice sounded anemic next to Nilsson has never heard the two divas on an actual operatic stage. <br />Different voices... Nilsson's voice is like a rocket roaring toward its listener while  Sutherland is like a gigantic wall of sound that surrounds you like a blanket. You cannot say that when large volumes are needed, Sutherland cannot deliver them. I've  heard her soar over the gigantic choruses in Beatrice di Tenda, holding a high E for 12 seconds! That note still rings in my ears. <br />Believe me, the high tessitura of Turandot is not a problem for Sutherland's voice. Remember, she is the only soprano in the world to sing Esclamonde - a role that demands high Ds, Es, and a high G. Esclamonde also required a full 120 piece Wagnerian size orchestra (think Gotterdamerung).And Sutherland does trills and staccato above the brass section! LIVE on the SF stage in 1974, I was in the audience. Her voice was titanic, especially the high Ds.<br />As Turandot, Sutherland did not attack every note with shere power as Nilsson did. The role did not required that every note be sung that way. Sutherland only launch her massive high notes when they were called for. In the moments that called for softer notes, she can deliver them with great beauty. Because she sung Turandot with a wide range of  dynamics makes her superior to Nilsson's, who belting her Turandot. Having said that, Birgit Nilsson was argueably the greatest Wagnerian dramatic soprano of the last century, edging out even the glorious Kirsten Flagstad. But I still think in the studio, Sutherland's Turandot rules.<br />Now for some trivia. Did you know that in La Scala, the Italians did not always like Nilsson's style of belting out every single note in Turandot? Puccini wrote the role with the idea of a very complicated woman who WANT to fall in love. I believe, it fact, that Turandot was in love with Calaf at first sight. And that's the feeling I get with Sutherland's Turandot. <br />To me, and thousands of others who rave this recording as the desert island version of Puccini's great masterpiece, Sutherland sang with just enough fortissimi  AND beauty of tone to make this a powerful Turandot to beat all others.<br />The same goes for Caballe's superlative Liu that is miraculous and Pavarotti's confident and honeyed voice Calaf.<br />This is opera making at its best. And those one star reviews are obviously jealous people who probably never even heard this performance. <br />Intelligent opera lovers, I challenge you to listen to this beauty and you be the judge. <br />Nilsson or Sutherland? I say Sutherland.

B00005JLPK|5.0|Before watching this movie I had no idea who Frida was.  I knew that the film was directed by Julie Taymor (Titus), which meant that it would have a striking visual style.  I knew that the movie starred Salma Hayek and that she had wanted to play this role for years.  I knew that it had been nominated for 6 Academy Awards including a Best Actress nomination for Hayek.  But I did not know anything about the subject of the film.<br />Frida is a biopic focusing on the life of Mexican artist Frida Kahlo (Salma Hayek).  As much as the movie focuses on the life of Frida, it seemed that the main thrust of picture was on Frida's relationship with her husband, painter Diego Rivera (Alfred Molina).  The film does cover Frida's life from her childhood right up to her death.  We begin the movie when Frida is a young woman aspiring to be a painter.  Her father is highly supportive of her dreams.  However, she is riding on a trolley one day when it gets into an accident.  She has to be in a body cast for some time and it was in doubt whether she would ever walk again.  She recovers, but she lives a life of pain.  Frida meets the womanizing painter, Diego Rivera and they get married.  This does not mean that he changes his ways and naturally this causes problems in their marriage.  They remain committed to each other even when they are each sleeping with other people.  Over the course of the movie we see Frida painting, but it seems that Frida the artist gets pushed to the side and we see Frida the woman/wife.  I don't know enough about Frida Kahlo to know if this is a flaw in the movie or not, but it is just the way the movie is.<br />The acting in this movie is superb.  Nothing feels wrong or forced.  But, surpassing even the excellent acting is the visual presentation of Frida.  Her artwork appears throughout the movie, but not simply as paintings hanging on the wall.  Kahlo's artwork appears first as a painting, but that painting transforms into the scene itself.  This also works the opposite way in that a scene will end up as a painting and the transitions between the two are so smooth it is very impressive.<br />I was very impressed with Frida.  I didn't care for Julie Taymos's other film (Titus), so I didn't know what to expect.  Everyone (Hayek, Taymor) exceeded my expectations for the movie.  This was a very good movie.o works the opposite way in that a scene will end up as a painting and the transitions between the two are so smooth it is very impressive. <br />I was very impressed with Frida. B00008LDPU|4.0|The Animatrix consists of nine animated short films that are part of the Matrix universe.  They deal with various aspects of the universe and some interact directly with the two movies.  As the films are each made by different directors/animation houses, they all have different looks and feels to them.  Each film is about 10 minutes long.  Naturally, some are better than others.<br />Final Flight of the Osiris:  This one is referenced near the beginning of the Matrix Reloaded.  This film has the crew of the Osiris discovering the Sentinel army drilling down to Zion.  Considering the title, we know what happens to the ship, but this is one of the better films of the bunch.  The animation was done by Square (the makers of the Final Fantasy movie) and it surpasses their previous work.  The CGI is so well done that at times you can forget that this is not real.<br />The Second Renaissance Parts I and II: These two films are connected.  These films are a prehistory to the Matrix.  We see how machines came into power and the war against Man and Machine.  In the Matrix we are told that man blotted out the sun.  In Part II we see how this is done.  This is essential viewing as it is the history document of the Matrix.  This is the how and the why the machines came to power and through it we see things that perhaps could have been done differently.  If only.<br />Kid's Story:  I didn't think this was that great of a short film, but it connects directly into the Matrix Reloaded.  There is a character in that movie trying to follow Neo around and says several times that Neo saved him.  Neo replies that he saved himself.  This is the story of that character and how he was freed from the Matrix.  I found this one interesting because of the connection to the movie, but that is the only reason.  This features the guest voices of Keanu Reeves and Carrie Anne Moss.<br />Program:  Most of this film is fight sequences between two people in what feels like a training program.  The man is trying to convince the woman that she needs to forget about the Matrix and the real world because while they wanted to know the truth, it would be better to live an artificial life in ignorance.  I liked some of the ideas of this film, but the presentation was somewhat lacking.<br />World Record:  I'll admit that I'm a geek for track and field.  This one features an athlete who broke the world record in the 100 meters in the prelims and wants to shatter his own record so that it will never be touched.  He also becomes someone who is unknowingly able to affect the Matrix (thus the world record).  It features slow motion action for the track portion as well as flashbacks of how he got to that point.  Interesting for me, but I'm not sure about anyone else.<br />Beyond: Beyond did not connect as well as some of the films to the Matrix, but it is probably going to become a favorite.  Beyond follows a young woman who lost her cat.  She (and several children) discover a \\"haunted\\" house where weird things happen.  Gravity and other laws of physics are able to be circumvented without any of the control that someone manipulating the Matrix would need.  A sweet little story.<br />A Detective Story: This is my favorite short film of the bunch.  This is done in black and white and is a classic detective story (like one would find in the stories of Marlowe).  The dectective (truly a stereotype character) is contacted to try to find a hacker named Trinity (yes, that Trinity).  It is a sweet little story and is visually impressive.  Features the guest voice of Carrie Anne Moss.<br />Matriculated: This is my least favorite of the bunch.  It did not make any sense to me.  It was the story of humans capturing a machine, hooking it up to the Matrix and trying to convert it to the cause of humanity.  Throughout the film there was a lot of strange visuals that reminded me of an Isaac Asimov story without any of the depth or plotting.  I found this to be the weakest of the bunch.man is trying to convince the woman that she needs to forget about the Matrix and the real world because while they wanted to know the truth, it would be better to live an artificial life in ignorance.  I liked some of the ideas of this film, but the presentation was somewhat lacking.  <br />World Record:  I'll admit that I'm a geek for track and field. Interesting for me, but I'm not sure about anyone else.  <br />Beyond: Beyond did not connect as well as some of the films to the Matrix, but it is probably going to become a favorite. B00005OM4Q|5.0|Almost Famous is very good, but Almost Famous Untitled - The Bootleg Cut (Director's Edition) has extra material that fills in the gaps that add so much more to the story.  I recommend that you don't pass it up if you can find it.
B00009TB5G|4.0|Be warned - this review is more about the relationship between the movie and the story and less about the movie itself.<br />I grew up with LOTR.  It was read to me as a bedtime story as a child and was re-read every couple of years since.  When hiking in forest or mountain, I amused myself by wondering if this is what Fangorn Forest, Emyn Muil or Mordor looked like and wondered if it was the wind moving the trees or if perhaps they were moving on their own.  I felt the age-old wisdom of the Ents, the pride of dwarves through Gimli, Aragorn's self-doubt and conflicts, and Faramir's nobility when over-coming the temptation of the Ring.  I named my first born Aragorn.  <br />I understood why Tom Bombadil, the Old Forest and much of the preamble had to go in The Fellowship of the Ring.  The teeter-totter staircase in the Mines of Moria was not needed, but forgiven by perfectly imagined Balrog.  The first movie stayed very close to the spirit of the book if not the story.<br />What I do not understand is why Peter Jackson felt it necessary to diverge so much from the spirit of the story in the Two Towers.  Why was it necessary to present Merry and Pippin as having changed the minds of the Ents when in the book the Ents arrive at the need to attack Isengard on their own?  Why present the Ents as jerky stick men?  Why needlessly have Faramir bring Frodo and Sam to Osgiliath instead of letting them go earlier on and thus presenting Faramir as a far more noble.  Why have Legolas and Gimli be some Middle-Earth version of Laurel and Hardy?  One giggle in The Fellowship was enough - the antics they put Gimli through in the Two Towers are completely unnecessary.<br />However - the scenes of Gollum's internal debate, the battle at Helm's Deep, the interaction between Theoden, Grima (Wormtongue) and Gandalf in Meduseld and Sam, Frodo and Gollum's walk through the Dead Marshes to the Gates of Mordor were awesome.  The scenes of mothers sending their very young sons off to battle at Helm's Deep were immensely powerful.  We even got see the caves of Helm's Deep to which Tolkien alluded but never described.<br />I wonder what else will be dropped or changed in Return of the King?  Will Aragorn travel the Paths of the Dead?  Will it be Eowyn who slays the Nazgul or is it Merry who becomes the hero?  Will Shelob look as bad as the Ents?<br />This movie could have been, should have been great, as it is, it's merely good.

B00005V9HA|5.0|Some may call it campy, and some may call it a waste of time.  I call it absolutely brilliant!<br />Re-animator is possibly the best horror/comedy film ever produced.  Filled with all the makings of a popular feature...blood, guts, sex, corpse chases, dead cats, it's no wonder that this film has become a cult classic.  It is phenomenally written, being cleverly \\"in your face\\" and \\"behind your back\\" at the same time.  If you're even considering buying this, you most likely know the plot and general happenings, so why should I waste your time bending your ear over it?  Suffice it to say, this movie has something for everyone, from the die-hard horror fan, to the connoisseur of fine satire.<br />The DVD is an absolutely fantastic package, and well worth whatever you pay for it.  Disc 1 contains the feature, remastered from the original, with a new and greatly improved soundtrack, resulting in a far superior presentation to the previously released VHS version (and to tell you the truth, better than a Laser-disc edition that I saw many years ago as well!).  Disc 2 is filled (yes, the entire disc) with interviews, outtakes, extra scenes, and special features far too numerous to be listed here.  We can only hope that when \\"Bride of Re-animator\\" is re-released later this year, that it receives the same consideration that the original did.<br />Being on so many \\"must have\\" lists must mean something, and I can personally tell you that you can't go wrong by adding this classic to your collection.  Probably not a good idea to let your kids watch this one, but if you really want to scare your cat...

B00005JKED|5.0|I'm not gonna run my fingers over the keyboard like everyone else trying to write an essay for college, I would'nt really even call this a review. The Academy Award nominated 'Training Day' is a terrific film using the remarkeable dramatic acting talents of both Ethan Hawke and Denzel Washington. It also takes the bar and raises it on gripping content in the dangerous world of police work, in this case narcotics in one of the most dangerous gang regions of the country. Taking place over a 24 hour period, decorated officer Alonso Harris molds and shapes a young, fresh-out-of-academy rookie beat cop (Hawke) into his idea of the LA narcotics officer that will get the job done right. Ethan Hawke slowely learns how rough of an edge the job has, where normal rules of Community Oriented Policing don't apply. In a powerfull scene during a raid of a drug kingpin's home, the line we're all so familiar with between what rules movie cops break and what lenghts are not gone to or discussed..is drawn what has to be the last possible time. I don't think anything done in the future with this kind of film or TV show could put a more surprising and shocking turn of events on police misconduct. Officer Harris' young trainee learns a new and untold meaning to 'Justifiable Homicide', what goes on behind closed doors of well-respected politicians and the cost of actually making the narcotics department work in this day and age...a cost that never makes the news quite the way it happens. I've read so many reviews from these four-eyed computer geek people who will sit here all day with their chocolate milk and tear the plot apart, complaining they 'don't understand why' this and they 'don't understand how' that...For instance the final confrontation in the film before Hawke hunts for his training officer, when Alonzo leaves for dead his trainee with the hispanic drug higher-ups. Not to give anything away, but if you listened to all the dialogue following the raid on Roger..when Denzel canbe heard saying \\"Make sure that bathtubs' clean ya hear?\\", you can piece together the plot as Alonzo, knowing the family to the young girl rookie Hawke saves from rape on the street, would know that Hawke would explain to the girl's cousin how he saved her in order to save his own life...I mean the movie IS called 'TRAINING Day'. The film produces incredibly well-done performances by both stars and supporting cast, and this could possibly be the LAST great police drama that sets you on the edge of your seat and makes you compare in your head the lies, crimes and daily events of law enforcement within the story to news and real events of police drama on the streets in this country. It holds it's ground, does'nt attempt to make anything seem more comforting to the viewers, and ends on a small audio note SO appropriate to the entire film it almost makes me cry its' so good.
B00003CXBH|5.0|I like that this movie doesn't really seem to have an agenda to push.  There are many complex themes that are dealt with, but at no point does the film try to say that one way is necessarily the right way.  Yes, it makes it's point very well that killing and/or enslaving people is wrong.  But beyond that, what surprised me is that it takes such a non-judgemental viewpoint of the work of missionaries.  I really appreciated that.<br />In other words, since I'm probably not organizing my thoughts very well, this movie deals with heavy issues but ultimately lets the viewer come to his/her own conclusions.<br />The performances from Jeremy Irons and DeNiro are first class.  If Irons shines brightest, I'd say it's because he has much more screentime and the script gave him a bit more to work with.  But I won't take anything away from DeNiro, this is a really different type of role for him and he is very affective.<br />I could go on, but I think this is a movie that really just needs to be experienced.  And don't be put off by the time period.  I'm not wild about period pieces, generally speaking, but I was engrossed in this movie right from the first scene to the last.  There are some truly unforgettable moments.<br />While I haven't listened to the director's commentary or viewed the documentary (yet), I will say that this is one awesome looking dvd.  Before checking out the dvd, I had seen the movie years ago on a pan-and-scan VHS rental.  I had heard so much praise for the cinematography and you'd never tell why from a tape.  Now I see why the first thing people often praise is the photography, it's outstanding.
0195073401|4.0|Firstly, take care to read the mathematical appendix. Just get used to the notation. Once you do, I think the math is not at all hard. If you are going to be a graduate economics student, you HAVE to be totally comfortable with the math used in here. And what they teach you in &quot;math camps&quot; or first-year &quot;math methods&quot; classes goes way beyond what is used here.<br />I think it's much more the notation that puts people off. Can anyone please point out where exactly the MATHEMATICS used in the book is arcane or inaccessible? Yes, some of the questions at the back are quite hard, but again a little perseverance and the purchase of the Segal/Hara/Tadelis review book and I think you can do well in your micro prelims.<br />It's much more the case that MWG's presentation is very formal as is their notation. Yet once you get past this, the mathematics employed is really just multi-variate calculus and a bit of matrix algebra.<br />Strength: chapters 13, 14,15,16,18,21,22,23. Really well laid out stuff. Section on adverse selection is really well-laid out. Problems at the back of chapters 13 and 14 are pretty interesting and actually can be solved through intuition alone.<br />Weakness: Too arcane and theoretical for consumer theory. By &quot;too arcane&quot; etc I really mean that most professors at most schools never seem to test you on proving (for instance) the rigorous results on quasi-concavity, strict concavity and the like. Rather they like small tricky problems with Slutsky matrices and Euler equations. Yet if you read MWG you will spend a lot of time (for example) poring through proofs of the continuity of the expenditure function and representation theorems for preferences. It is true that Profs lecture and set problems out of Varian on this stuff and then rather cruelly give you MWG as the &quot;reference text.&quot; <br />Producer theory: this is really useless, except for some nice diagrams on cost and output. But again a good intermediate text has this too. Again most professors most places do not set the sort of problems you find at the back of MWG.<br />Intermediate: game theory. Relevant problems and good examples, but you can get too bogged down in writing out strategy sets and correspondences and the like.<br />But: overall my criticisms of this book are linked mainly to the discrepancy between actual teaching practises and the content of the book. As a self-contained book, MWG presents matters formally and maybe a bit tediously, but it does provide a feel for the elegance of modern, mathematical economic theory.<br />I learned this too late for my own good, but one other advice to users of this book: abandon the math when you solve the problems. There are lots of problems in here that primarily test your ability to set up problems and your intuition.
B00009V7T2|5.0|When Cedrick and Omar left At The Drive-In at the brink of stardom many people thought they had lost their minds. At the Drive-In had achieved a rare combination of commercial and critical success and several music publications had pegged them as the next Nirvana. Nevertheless Cedrick and Omar knew they could never create the music they desired to create in that setting. After breaking up ATDI they assembled a cast of supermusicians and consolidated under the name The Mars Volta. Their debut album Deloused in the Comatorium attests to the power of their creative vision. A stunning fusion of Post-Hardcore, Prog-Rock, Free-Jazz, Classic Rock, and Salsa; it could be the most revolutionary rock album since Radiohead's Ok Computer. The visceral energy and creative songwriting of ATDI remain, however the standard Post-Hardcore backdrop has been replaced with a style all their own. The emotional and intelligent themes of their past work also remain. The entire album is a tribute the the late Julio Venegas, a close friend of the band who commited suicide in 1996. It is a fictional account of the visions he possibly experienced in a coma following a failed suicide attempt, however the lyrics are often abstract and it is possible to derive your own meaning from them. This is a must-buy for any fan of quality music.
B00001QEBQ|3.0|This is a story that the whole family liked and we watched it several times, but then interest waned.  My little ones will go through phases of watching a new disney movie to dead, then it wanes to &quot;periodic&quot;.  This one was never an obsession for anyone in the family, not has anyone asked to see it lately.<br />I thought the problems might be the medium coloring, but they watch the &quot;power puff girls&quot;, and disneys worst isn't ever close to being that bad.  I also didn't care for the digtal imaging job that was done... almost as if it was rushed.  I thought the action was good and the characters interesting, so I think it was the music.  The music here is mediocre to bad.  The music can make a big difference.  What would the Hunchback of Notre Dame be without that wonderful music!
B000002UAX|4.0|Well, alright...no, not all of the songs are good, and some aren't even songs.  The ones that are songs tend to be very, very good, although some of those tend to suffer from the Beatle tendency to put nonsense lyrics in songs.  I have always believed they did that to (1) make people think they were putting is something deep, and (2) because they couldn't think of anything else that sounded good.  In a way, (2) is the most satisfying because only the Beatles got away routinely with the use of lyrics that make absolutely no sense.  But, like Shakespeare, they wrote in language that is so in tune with the way we all think (or thought, since this album came out so many years ago) that the songs are almost guaranteed to be easily memorable and therefore hits.  And that is part of the magic of this album...no matter what songs you pick as favorites, or which ones you pan as ridiculous, the power of the Beatles as songwriters that play right into the way you talk and think is unmistakeable.  However, there is a lot of stuff on this album that nobody but the Beatles could include and have everyone think of as high art.  Everyone thinks the Beatles burned all kinds of artistic midnight oil tweaking numerous meaningful details, including all kinds of twisty clues to this and that.  OK...probably on some things, but going overboard with that kind of thing has helped make mountains out of &quot;songs&quot; on this album that are really molehills.  And, it has made songs that are pure fun, and were meant only for that, to be examined and found philosophically wanting by people that look for those hidden meaings.  To conclude, the Beatles emptied their attic on this album.  Like any collection of stuff from an attic, some of it very interesting and some of it is simply to be thrown away.  Having said that, though, remember that beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and this album has found beauty in lots and lots of eyes.  It really is a hoot to listen to, and it really really is a great collection from the 20th century's most influential rock band.  You won't regret going through this collection of attic rummage and finding what you like, because you will find things that you like, and like a lot.
0316666343|1.0|I read this book rather reluctantly. My roomate gave it to me months ago and I had no intention of reading it, but curiosity got the best of me. I wanted to know if it was really as good as everyone was making it out to be. Needless to say, I was let down. It did not hold my interest and I ended up skimming through many parts of the book. The last two chapters were so corny and far fetched it was almost laughable. <br />It wasn't the subject matter that bothered me. The story lacked a sense of cohesiveness. It was very disjointed and I felt that most of the characters were poorly devloped and not very believable. I don't understand why the literary world has placed so much esteem on this book. Does the author have friends in high places? That is the only explanation I can come up with. If you are looking for a page-turner (with a satisfying ending) try A Thousand Acres by Jane Smiley or White Oleander by Janet Fitch.
B00004W50T|5.0|When \\"...Big Pink\\" came out in 1968 I was 21 years old, in the Navy, and a long way from home.  I had just learned that the music which spoke to me so strongly, but was heard on the radio so rarely, was called Blues.  I don't know which cut I heard first -- probably The Weight -- but whatever it was spoke to me as clearly as Sonny Boy Williamson and Eric Clapton.  A thread which was woven through the psychedelic era was a wish by young adults to get back to the land, to eschew the suburban life in which we'd been reared and return to self-reliance and uncomplicated values. The Band let us return in our hearts to somewhere we'd never been, and Music From Big Pink will forever be one of the seminal albums of the Baby Boom's lives.  The wonderful thing about it is that it holds up, does not go out of date.  It is musical literature, and will never die.

B00005B4GD|5.0|At long last, the Brothers Gibb have crafted an album that surpasses all their earlier efforts. The sound is more basic (less synthesizer) and more mature (simplifying all their talents). The range is varied, but always maintains an upbeat, rock filled tempo. &quot;She Keeps On Coming&quot; and &quot;Voice In The Wilderness&quot; are amazing surprises of excellent R &amp; B rock. Is this the Bee Gees? Even the ballads are mainstream upbeat, such as, &quot;Wedding Day&quot;, &quot;Embrace&quot; and the oddly named, &quot;Loose Talk, Costs Lives&quot;. Although, the title track has been chosen as the first single (in the rest of the World), any track could make it, (save for &quot;Technicolor Dreams&quot;, which is a pleasant, but odd novelty song). Maurice even tops himself with the Beach Boys styled &quot;Man In The Middle&quot; and &quot;Walking On Air&quot;. There are lots of surprises here and there is absolutely no way to try and pick which songs will be chosen for air-play. They are all that good.  It doesn't hurt to go out of the way to get the extra songs on this package, such as the lovely ballad, &quot;Just In Case&quot; and the power song, &quot;Promise The Earth&quot;.

The sound is more basic (less synthesizer) and more mature (simplifying all their talents). The range is varied, but always maintains an upbeat, rock filled tempo. &quot;She Keeps On Coming&quot; and &quot;Voice In The Wilderness&quot; are amazing surprises of excellent R &amp; B rock. Is this the Bee Gees? Even the ballads are mainstream upbeat, such as, &quot;Wedding Day&quot;, &quot;Embrace&quot; and the oddly named, &quot;Loose Talk, Costs Lives&quot;. Although, the title track has been chosen as the first single (in the rest of the World), any track could make it, (save for &quot;Technicolor Dreams&quot;, which is a pleasant, but odd novelty song). Maurice even tops himself with the Beach Boys styled &quot;Man In The Middle&quot; and &quot;Walking On Air&quot;. There are lots of surprises here and there is absolutely no way to try and pick which songs will be chosen for air-play. They are all that good. It doesn't hurt to go out of the way to get the extra songs on this package, such as the lovely ballad, &quot;Just In Case&quot; and the power song, &quot;Promise The Earth&quot;.

B00005QK3W|4.0|As a big fan of The Beatles and of Paul's early solo stuff, I must admit that it's been twenty years since I've bought anything Paul has done. The `80's and `90's were a LONG dry spell.<br />\\"Flaming Pie\\" and now, \\"Driving Rain\\". Paul is BACK!<br />Driving Rain, like The Beatles' White Album, is a sprawling (16 tracks!) musical collage, but with a distinct, sometimes barely perceptible (sometimes noticeably so), undercurrent of darkness...\\"edginess\\". Both albums attempt to cover a lot of ground, both suffer from an occasional misstep, both have shining successes despite their lack of \\"Top 40\\" material, and both are somewhat polarizing to fans. The White Album and Driving Rain. You either love `em or you hate `em.<br />I love Driving Rain.<br />The opening track \\"Lonely Road\\" sets the tone immediately. Melancholy lyrics, gritty guitars, and a gravelly vocal serves notice that Paul intends to ROCK on this CD, thank you very much.<br />\\"From a Lover to a Friend\\" is Paul's obvious attempt at a radio-friendly tune. It begins promisingly enough, but Paul's voice thins as he hits the high notes and the \\"oooo-la-la-la's\\" are a put off.<br />\\"She's Given Up Talking\\" seems to have taken a lot of flak from other reviewers, mostly, I guess, because the lyrics are something less than \\"Eleanor Rigby\\". I'm sorry, but Paul's thumping fuzz bass and a guitar solo that had me convinced that Pink Floyd's David Gilmour was sitting in make this a very strong track indeed. Unlike anything else in Macca's catalog.<br />\\"Driving Rain\\", again, seems to be a favorite song to pick on by some of the reviewers in the crowd because they feel Paul's opening verse, \\"1-2-3-4-5/Let's go for a drive!\\" is, I dunno, \\"unworthy\\". Are they even LISTENING to Paul's melodious bass perfectly looping in and around the punchy staccato drum/rhythm guitar combo? Pop craftsmanship at its best. <br />\\"I Do\\" is very nice, but in my opinion suffers from just a tad bit too much over-production. Streamline the orchestra, and it sounds like it's right off of Rubber Soul.<br />\\"Tiny Bubble\\" has a Motown feel that morphs into a signature Paul sing-a-long. Nice ditty but nothing earthshaking.<br />\\"Magic\\" falls a bit short to my ears. Generic melody, uninspired lyrics. Saved somewhat by Beatle-like false ending and drum solo fade out reminiscent of \\"Strawberry Fields\\".<br />\\"Your Way\\" is yet another showcase for Paul's wonderful ability to marry bass and guitar into a very simple, yet very enjoyable little country tune. Think of  Ram's \\"Heart of the Country\\" or Red Rose Speedway's  \\"One More Kiss\\".<br />\\"Spinning on an Axis\\" never really gets going. Paul's \\"rap\\" makes me cringe.<br />\\"About You\\" is quite possibly my favorite. WOW! Straight ahead power pop/blues that jumps right in and takes no prisoners. The bass! The vocal! The DRUMMING! WOW! Did I say WOW? Could find a home on White Album/Let it Be/Abbey Road. WOW!<br />\\"Heather\\" is an almost completely instrumental piano track named for Paul's new wife. The story goes, he was playing the tune at home when Heather asked, \\"Which Beatle song is that?\\" Very nice melody. I love the line that Paul eventually sings, \\"There I will stay/for a year and a day\\". I'm not sure why, other than it sounds like just the kind of whimsy we all loved from the \\"old\\" (or is it \\"young\\"?) Paul.<br />\\"Back in the Sunshine Again\\", in my opinion, is actually Paul's tribute to George (not the sitar-tinged \\"Riding Into Jaipur\\"). A bluesy number with George-like slide guitar work throughout. Another rather gritty offering that is not at all \\"sunshiney\\". A favorite.<br />\\"Your Loving Flame\\". Ugh. It's the return of `80's Paul! This is why I stopped buying! Syrupy Muzak with little if any redeeming value. Skip.<br />\\"Riding Into Jaipur\\". I didn't much care for The Beatles' Indian influenced tunes, and I still don't care for them now. Points for trying, I guess, but \\"Back in the Sunshine\\" sounds to me like much more of a \\"George\\" song than this does.<br />\\"Rinse the Raindrops\\" has very strong echoes of Abbey Road's \\"I Want You (She's So Heavy)\\". I LOVE this song! Again, WOW! A ten minute jam with tons of little Beatle flourishes: primal scream, backward guitar, harpsichord and cello combo. A delicious treat. Can you see any of Paul's contemporaries (Eric Clapton, Elton John, Mick Jagger, etc.) recording anything like this? No way in hell! Would have been the absolutely perfect ending to the album except...<br />...\\"Freedom\\" got slapped on at the last minute in response to 9/11. Oh, it's an OK song I guess, but after the utter bliss of \\"Rinse the Raindrops\\", I never let this track come on to spoil the mood.<br />Paul has produced back-to-back superb efforts for the first time since \\"Band on the Run\\" and \\"Venus and Mars\\". Can he hit the trifecta with his next record? For the first time in a long time, he's got momentum!

B000002BYD|5.0|On Yield, Pearl Jam's 5th album, the band abandons much of the experimental nature of the preceding two albums (No Code and Vitalogy) and offers up a strong batch of classic rock tunes.  The band is older and wiser, not afraid to let loose and rock out.  This attitude creates an album that feels very organic and rich.  Eddie's vocals are in top form and the guitar interplay between Stone Gossard and Mike McCready reaches a whole new level of excellence.  Yield truly is a band effort and it shows.  <br />\\"Brain of J\\" is one of Pearl Jam's greatest album openers; it opens the album on a VERY energetic note and the lyrics are based on some very interesting subject matter.  Following \\"Brain of J\\" is another highlight in \\"Faithfull\\".  The song starts out whisper soft and explodes into a rocking chorus, showing Pearl Jam's uncanny sense of dynamics.  The one-two punch of \\"Given to Fly\\" and \\"Wishlist\\" is one of the finest moments in Pearl Jam's history, two of their greatest songs one after the other.  \\"Low Light\\"  is a great acoustic ballad with tons of emotion; for some reason Pearl Jam neglects to play this great song live.  \\"In Hiding\\" is Yield's last excellent song, perhaps the best song on the album:  a very classic rock, Neil Young reminiscent song with a vocal melody to die for.  The rest of the songs range from decent (\\"Push Me Pull Me, \\"Red Dot\\") to great (\\"MFC\\", \\"All Those Yesterdays\\").  <br />Yield isn't \\"comeback to grunge CD\\" that fans of Ten and Vs. have been wishing for, but rather a showcase for a band that experimented, took what they learned, and injected it into their current sound.  This album is an absolute must-have if you are a fan of Pearl Jam's previous efforts, especially No Code.  If you are looking to get into Pearl Jam you should definitely start with Ten and Vs.  As it stands, Yield is another high quality offering from the best band of the 90's.

B000077VOY|5.0|Stingray is part three in the Gerry Anderson five part development (and eventual perfection) of marionette based shows. 'Supercar\\" was crude and campy good 1960 kidshow fun. \\"Fireball XL5\\" had significant improvements in technique. \\"Stingray\\" was in color and was a dramatic leap ahead in set design, marionette action, scripting, and special effects. \\"Thunderbirds\\" remains the best of the lot with hour long scripts, \\"gee whiz!\\" special effects, some funny character development (such as the humourously  irritable dialogue of the pyramid explorers in \\"The Uninvited\\"), and action scenes. Stingray is famous for its underwater special effects which were advanced for 1963-64. No one had seen anything like it up until then. Stingray has the best fully developed characters with Troy, Phones, Atlanta, and Marina. Stingray is enjoyable and highly nostalgic.

Along the way he faces difficulties, overcomes them, and acquires the ability to speak the &quot;Language of the World&quot; (the ability to communicate with sentient beings of the world). As a modern day fable, the book possesses neither the compendious quality of R. Bach's &quot;Jonathan Livingston Seagull&quot; nor the warmth and imagination of Saint-Exupery's &quot;The Little Prince.&quot; The indicative mood employed by the author leaves readers with almost no space for imagination. It comes to me as a surprise that this book has been such a hit. Perhaps we are all ears when it comes to fables.

6305132984|5.0|I won't have any original commentary to add here after more than 200 reviews. But I remember when this film ran on network television 25 years ago. After being beefed up with commercials, it had to be shown in 2 parts over two nights. I only saw it in the theater once when I was about 14, and had forgotten many  visuals which were cut off on television. So let me just say that the smartest thing MGM-UA could do is present a widescreen, 70mm DVD. It has a gorgeous restored picture (important for visual effects during the gym dance and the rumble, which saturate the screen with the color red), and pristine sound- probably the most gorgeous score ever composed by Leonard Bernstein. There are, of course, stage purists who scoff at the movie (and its many ghost singers), but I always thought the film's adaptation was superior to the stage show because it gave the story a more breathless, one-act pace. The songs \\"Cool\\" and \\"I Feel Pretty\\" are completely restaged from the original libretto, and the background score is given something of a theatrical makeover. And the dancing, of course, is peerless-- whether it's the \\"Cool\\" dance in the garage, the \\"America\\" battle of the sexes featuring the Sharks, or even the delicate rooftop solo performed by Natalie Wood- radiant and bewitching in a white dress.
