0609610570|4.0|A big fan of Ram Charan, I was looking forward to reading Execution. I started the book twice and couldn't get through it (I suspect good intentions, but poor execution on my part.) Upon the third attempt, I made it all the way through and found the book to be extremely valuable. <br />As an HR person, I often struggle with finding reasons for the success of some people and organizations to get things done while others simply talk about things and cannot deliver results.  It is often our role to lead the leaders and to help build the capability of our people. The authors attribute much of the ability to execute to strong leadership, corporate culture, and systematic processes with regard to: people, strategy, and operations. CEO's are finally realizing that having the right talent in the first place is critical to delivering high performance results.<br />The first part of this book is cumbersome. Moving back and forth between Larry and Ram conversation was distracting, and I think that is why some didn't find the book valuable. If you move quickly through that section, you will discover the best parts of the book.<br />First, that execution happens because of a corporate culture that is steeped in discipline. That very word may make some people bristle. Larry and Ram are not talking about punitive treatment of people (a la &quot;neutron Jack&quot;), but more of consistent processes and systems that can be replicated across a culture, in strategic business units, with repeatable results. It puts responsibility where it belongs, with corporate leaders. Leaders must be authentic and hands on. Leaders must know what is going on, must hold people accountable, and must communicate on a daily basis with people at all levels.<br />I openly admit that as an HR leader, I am biased. I was delighted to read from a CEO the reality that leaders cannot hand off responsibilities such as performance management, corporate culture building, talent review, and rewards and incentives to HR. Having the right people in place is the leader's responsibility. So leaders must take an active role in those processes. Yet many of my HR counterparts struggle to get in the CEO's office to discuss these topics.<br />According to the authors, a surprising number of strategies fail because leaders are not realistic about the capability of an organization to execute against a strategic plan. It never occurs to them that the right talent may not be in place or available, or that the culture or structure may not support the necessary changes.<br />My favorite part of the book was the section on getting the right people in the right jobs. The failings of the traditional interview process, performance, and rewards systems leads to poor fit between job and leader. Using a leadership assessment summary to give an overview of those who are promotable based on predetermined success factors can give a good view of the leadership pipeline and organizational capability. <br />While written for the general business reader, Human resources professionals will be the biggest fans of Execution. I hope it leads to consistent people, strategy, and operational processes in many organizations that will undoubtedly result in building a culture that gets things done. And, I hope many CEO's will read it and take action.
B00005QZWI|5.0|I think that one of the reasons why this soundtrack and the music that it contains is so fitting for the movie is because it fits in so seamlessly that it is a part of the story. The fact that Howard Shore composed this massive score for three movies, never mind one, is absolutely astounding. I know that a lot of people have always disregarded classical music because it is BORING, or whatever, but I think that people who appreciate classical music are actually very lucky. I personally play the clarinet, so the fact is that since I actually play in bands, and have experienced how many parts go into the making of each sound you hear, I am able to notice those little things that people sometimes miss. My favorite parts are not only the huge sweeping epic triumphs that are contained within this cd, but also the background sounds, such as strings that you don't even notice at first, and that little run that just adds something, you know? This soundtrack is not just about how big and massive and extraordinary the music is, but the fact that it contains so many memorable and enchanting solos and small parts that fit together so perfectly is equally remarkable. The singing solos are absolutely amazing, too. I didn't realize that the human voice could sound so beautiful. After having to listen to what is on the radio (such as rap, hip hop, etc), I start to realize how little real talent those people have. You may be thinking that I am some grouchy old person who is against all of today's popular music, but I'm not - I'm 15. I know that I am writing this review long after the soundtrack has come out, but this soundtrack is just so amazing and powerful and moving that I had to say something. If you are considering buying this cd, by all means do so. You certainly won't regret it.
B00008LDPU|3.0|Before watching this dvd I was all in favor of its concept.  Normally, great movies rarely give the audience a chance to fully understand the background of the story, but this dvd promises to do just that.  To that it, end only marginally succeeds.<br />This dvd collects nine stories from the Matrix universe, some that directly tie into the movies, and others that do not.  This, in my mind, is where the dvd's problems arise.  The stories involving known characters and events are wonderful, but the wholly original works lack spirit and direction.  <br />I gave this dvd 3 stars because the short episodes about the war with the machines, the discovery of the digging machines, and the search for Trinity all work wonderfully, if a bit unfocused.  The downfall is in the other tales using characters with no tie to anything except the universe they are in.<br />In my opinion, this dvd would have worked much better if it had gone into more detail about the rise of AI, as well as other points the movie's only mention.  The different artistic styles only fueled the lack of focus of these stories.  Either the creators were trying to push to much info through in a short time span, or the artists took too many liberties with the script.<br />This dvd also has some interesting extras.  Insight into its creation as well as others provide a small amount of enjoyment besides the films.  These, however, are no reason to purchase the dvd if you are not a fan of the films, all of which can be seen online fairly easily.<br />All in all, this dvd is an interesting companion to the Matrix films, but it is probably best to rent instead of purchase.

B0000262QW|5.0|&quot;Return to Forever&quot; is a marvelous album that stands in a genre all its own. Chick Corea has unassailable jazz credentials with his work in Miles' Davis experiments and his fine trio work with Roy Haynes and Miroslav Vitous. Return to Forever is a lyrical album that has beautiful melodies and strong improvisation from Joe Farrell while tastefully melding the Brazilian influences of Flora Purim and Airto Moreira. For me, it's the Brazilian influences that make this such a resounding album. Airto's samba patterns and percussive work on &quot;Return to Forever&quot; and &quot;Sometime Ago&quot; are wonderful. Joe Farrell provides some marvelous flute work on &quot;What Game Shall We Play Today&quot;. &quot;What Game&quot; is a very infectious melody that you'll want to play over and over again. Stanley Clarke's stuff is a little more restrained than some of the more rock influenced stuff Return to Forever eventually went into, but his technical chops are still a vital part of this session. Still &quot;Return to Forever&quot; highlights the best of what Chick Corea has to offer, a willingness to please, tasteful use of texture through the electric piano and music that takes risk while still being melodic and affirming. This is one of the best albums I've purchased in the last couple years.

Up on the level of film works like Blade Runner, 2001 &amp; Akira. Intentional or not, it also pays homage to great sci-fi books like William Gibsons Neuromancer and Frank Herberts Dune.<br />For a long time Japanese animation has picked up the slack of good sci-fi storytelling and concepts that most American sci-fi films have neglected. Look at Ghost in the Shell. The fact that the Matrix films are encompassing the deeper aspects of what makes good science fiction into something that the largely gullable American public can digest is wonderful. Like great science fiction, I will return to this stuff again and again to be taken in awe at the creative and intellectual forces that made this.<br />I can't wait for the third film.

B000002KIE|5.0|The best punk album ever made, and of course it's British!  Those Brits really got the pop culture thing down, don't they?  I mean, the Sex Pistols, the Clash, the Slits... Well, never mind the you-know-what--here's the review for the Sex Pistols.<br />With martial stomping and a blaring angry guitar roar, the Cold War angst of \\"Holiday In The Sun,\\" one of my three favourites on this classic punk album rings off with references to Nazi concentration camps, the Berlin Wall, and maybe homophobia as well:  \\"...I was waiting for the Communist call/I didn't ask for sunshine/and I got World War III/I'm looking over the wall/and they're looking at me.\\"  Love that chanting of \\"reason reason\\" over the later verses!<br />The angry abortion thrash of \\"Bodies\\" is about Pauline from Birmingham, but at times, tells it from the would-be baby's POV.  The lyrics are harsh and unrelenting:  \\"Throbbing squirm, gurgling bloody mess/I'm not a discharge I'm not a loss in<br />protein I'm not a throbbing squirm Ah!\\"<br />\\"Feelings\\" is a song dealing with selfishness:  \\"I got no feelings/A-no feelings/for anybody else/(Except for myself<br />my beautiful self dear).\\"<br />\\"Liar\\" deals with reasons people lie, and there's that whiny and insistent and repetitive words motif that comes out:  \\"Lie lie lie lie liar you lie/lie lie lie lie tell me why tell me why.\\"  And so on.<br />In the black militant phrase, \\"you're either part of the problem or part of the solution,\\" the Pistols would go with the former:  \\"the problem is you!\\" in the song \\"Problems.\\"  One verse foretells the boring dead-end drudgery foretelling the corporate 80's:  \\"Eat your heart out on plastic tray/you don't do what you want/then you'll fade away/You won't find me working nine to five/it's too much fun a-being alive.\\"  Another great lyric:  \\"Don't you give me any orders/for people like me there is no order.\\"<br />For six weeks, the top song on the British charts was a long black line, and it is one of their signature tunes.  Everybody now:  \\"God save the Queen/the fascist regime/they made you a moron/a potential H-bomb/God save the Queen/she ain't no human being/There is no future/in England's dreaming.\\"  And love that nihilistic message:  \\"No future, no future for you.\\"  Note:  I heard somewhere that Paul McCartney used the verse \\"flowers in the dustbin,\\" and changed it to Flowers In The Dirt for his 1989 solo album.<br />The real punk attitude is brought out in \\"Seventeen\\":  \\"I don't work/I just speed/that's all I need.\\"<br />OK, signature tune number two, one that needs no song elaboration.  Ready everyone?  \\"I am an anti-Christ/I am an anarchist,/don't know what I want/but I know how to get it/I wanna destroy the passer by/'cos I wanna be anarchy/No dogsbody.\\"<br />The pace slows down a bit on \\"Sub-Mission\\" but comes back up on \\"Pretty Vacant,\\" another favourite here.  Apart from the \\"we're so pretty/oh so pretty/we're vacant/and we don't care,\\" there's another line that makes me laugh:  \\"I got no reason it's all too much/You'll always find us/out to lunch.\\"  Joan Jett covers this on The Hit List, BTW.<br />The final angry burst of sound that's \\"EMI\\" rails at the record distribution company and mainstream music:  \\"And blind acceptance is a sign/of stupid fools who stand in line like EMI.\\"  Joan Jett later did a version of this song called \\"MCA\\" against her own record label.<br />For Punk 101--the Classic Years, this is the proverbial one to get, then the Clash's self-titled one.  Just don't uproot too many trees, okay?verybody now:  \\"God save the Queen/the fascist regime/they made you a moron/a potential H-bomb/God save the Queen/she ain't no human being/There is no future/in England's dreaming.\\"  And love that nihilistic message:  \\"No future, no future for you.\\"  Note:  I heard somewhere that Paul McCartney used the verse \\"flowers in the dustbin,\\" and changed it to Flowers In The Dirt for his 1989 solo album.<br />The real punk attitude is brought out in \\"Seventeen\\":  \\"I don't work/I just speed/that's all I need.\\"<br />OK, signature tune number two, one that needs no song elaboration. B00008J2DQ|2.0|Before the official release of \\"Faceless\\" Godsmack singer Sully Erna made a bold statement to the metal world and press by saying \\" I can guarantee you one thing right now, nobody is going to sound like this !#!$##$# record! I know bands said this before but that's b#@$#$#!. Staind, P.O.D, Korn I don't care they won't sound like this record!\\" Though it's quite true that in metal right now nobody with the exception of Metallica is sticking to metal and hard rock through classic roots of Led Zeppelin and Black Sabbath like Godsmack are, that doesn't mean that they have recorded a jaw dropping original masterpiece. Though Sully and company are overly excited and proud about this new material, it seems that the average metal listener has heard similar material before, not just through Godsmack's first two albums but through classic bands such as Alice In Chains and Metallica. Though Godsmack were never known for their originality, they knew how to take the best elements of grunge,metal, and hard rock and make it to a catchy radio friendly album \\"Godsmack\\". However that album didn't satisfy more metal hungry goers, which led Godsmack's credibility to be questioned. This led Godsmack to release a heavier, more industrial induced follow up \\"Awake\\". However many fans believed that Godsmack were using the same riffage as Sevendust and Alice In Chains. So now comes Faceless. \\"I can guarantee you one thing right now\\" It's now going to stop the critics that have questioned Godsmack for so long. The album is not horribly bad, there are great hooks and riffs scattered through the album, yet Godsmack play it safe and play similar material from their first and second album. \\"Straight out of Line\\" the first catchy single covered all to familiar territory from their first album but it's just less radio friendly. The track \\"Faceless\\" sounds like \\"Awake\\"s little cousin. \\"I Stand Alone\\" and \\"Dead and Broken\\" are catchy too but nothing special. Finally the last tracks sound like leftoversongs from \\"Godsmack\\" and \\"Awake\\" sessions that weren't good enough to make it on those albums. Though it's obvious that Godsmack weren't going to make a radical departure, it would have been nice if they at least been more creative with their lyrics \\"I F!#$&$ Hate you anyone!\\" Well Godsmack lovers will love this album and that's fine. But if you are a casual fan and really want to buy one of their albums then I suggest you might as well get Faceless since it has a lot of elements from their prior albums and very little new elements. Well, at least the new album art is cool.

B000096FUD|5.0|It seems no director is truly given the title of genius until he has at least one project that never makes it to fruition.  The same can be said for Orsen Welles, & even Walt Disney, who had several projects that never made it, including the recently-discovered 1946 collaboration with Salvador Dali entitled 'Destino'.  Anyway, as an avid fan of Terry Gilliam's since I first saw 'Brazil' at the age of 12, no other single director, with the possible exception of George Lucas, has stimulated my imagination to the degreee this man has.  A true auteur in every sense of the word, Gilliam is more akin to a musician, releasing a morsel of genius every 5 years or so to whet his fans' appetites.  Having not heard from the man since 1998's 'Fear & Loathing in Las Vegas' also starring Johhny Depp, I have been in dire need of a Gilliam fix for some time.  Of course the lavish & well-deserved DVD treatment some of his new & older films have received has made the wait more bearable.  Then I heard rumors he was directing Neil Gaiman's 'Good Omens' several years back, & my hope began to return.  After not hearing anything about that failed project for the next couple of years, I was again excited to hear he was adapting Don Quixote into a trademarked Gilliam-black comedy-timetravel-eyecandy piece his fandom had been waiting for.  Cut to 2 years later & reading about the horrific end this film came to, the health problems, set problems, & overall bad karma that seems to follow Gilliam around like bad B.O.  Then 'Lost in La Mancha' came to be & I was dying to see it in a theater.  Well, living in Tennessee, you can imagine it never got this far.  Anyway, I'm glad to see this FINALLY released on DVD in this country, having been out in Europe for several months now.  It's not much of a time pill, & Terry is getting close to his 70th birthday, but I still believe the man will grace us with his vision again, & hopefully be recognized as the true genius he is, before he leaves us for thatgreat financial pirate ship in the sky...

0385504209|2.0|Although an interesting read, I do NOT encourage anyone to read The DaVinci Code.  This book is a blatant continuation of a centuries-old attack on the deity of Jesus Christ and a call for the return of paganism.  The \\"proof\\" that Jesus Christ is not God, nor claimed to be God, is none other than the works of Leonardo DaVinci...of course, the fact that DaVinci lived 1500 years after Christ does not deter Dan Brown from concluding that DaVinci's work is more credible than the contemporaries of Jesus Christ who recorded Jesus Christ's own words, such as, \\"I and the Father are one,\\" which is the reason why the religious leaders of the day sought to kill him (see John 10:30 & 31).<br />To refute the Gospels that were written by eye-witnesses, Brown alludes to the gnostic gospels which were not written during the first generation of the Church and were written as the first attacks against the deity of Jesus Christ. Surprisingly, although Brown considers Jesus Christ a pivotal person in history, he never brings up the most significant reason that Jesus Christ changed time as we know it (B.C. and A.D.): over 500 people, including the Roman soldiers guarding his tomb, witnessed his resurrection from the dead and his ascension into heaven a month and a half later!<br />What makes this an intriguing read is that in trying to build a case for worship of the goddess, Brown uses imagery from the Garden of Eden-a biblical theme.  The innocent Eve, Sophie Neveu, is being tempted by both the knowledgeable but naive Adam, Robert Langdon, and by the devil himself: the deceptive and terribly capable, Sir Leigh Teabing. In Brown's story, Adam prevails over the devil because of Eve and Eve is exalted as the pinnacle of creation.  That's a noble story but Brown creates it by debasing the deity of Jesus Christ and the history of Christianity.<br />In Brown's tale, Mary Magdalene, not the Apostle Peter, is the rightful \\"head\\" of the Church (which is not an accurate statement of St. Peter's role as defined by Jesus Christ anyway). Mary Magdalene, the supposed wife of Jesus Christ, is the beloved disciple, not the Apostle John.  It was the male disciples who, in Brown's tale, are anti-women and who in order to build an empire, suppressed the truth about Jesus and Mary and about Mary's rightful role.  However, Brown fails to re-state that for this empire, all of Jesus Christ's disciples (except for John) suffered excrutiating deaths for their belief that Jesus Christ was God come in the flesh (St. Peter was crucified on a cross up-side down; others were boiled alive, cut in half, fed to lions...and so it continued for three centuries under various Roman rulers!).<br />Apparently, Brown hopes his tale will convince nominal Catholics, Mormons who accept \\"extra-scripture\\" texts, and other religiously-minded people who are vaguely aware of who Jesus Christ is and who recognize DaVinci, Mozart and Newton, among others, as historical and therefore credible figures.  My advice: Don't spend the money.'s role as defined by Jesus Christ anyway). Mary Magdalene, the supposed wife of Jesus Christ, is the beloved disciple, not the Apostle John.  It was the male disciples who, in Brown's tale, are anti-women and who in order to build an empire, suppressed the truth about Jesus and Mary and about Mary's rightful role.  However, Brown fails to re-state that for this empire, all of Jesus Christ's disciples (except for John) suffered excrutiating deaths for their belief that Jesus Christ was God come in the flesh (St. Peter was crucified on a cross up-side down; others were boiled alive, cut in half, fed to lions...and so it continued for three centuries under various Roman rulers!).  <br />Apparently, Brown hopes his tale will convince nominal Catholics, Mormons who accept \\"extra-scripture\\" texts, and other religiously-minded people who are vaguely aware of who Jesus Christ is and who recognize DaVinci, Mozart and Newton, among others, as historical and therefore credible figures.  My advice: Don't spend the money.

B000078DOI|5.0|Mother's Milk is the Peppers 4th album released before their masterpiece Blood Sugar Sex Magik. This is their first album with new guitarist John Frusciante, and drummer Chad Smith replacing respectively the deceased Hillel Slovak and Jack Irons. Both new members prove their importance to the band with guitar salvos reminescent of Hendrix by Frusciante, and the tight rhythm and powerful style of Smith. Original members Flea and Anthony Kiedis bring the funk as well. Flea's bass style had become increasingly virtousic over the albums and his bass shines throughout. Anthony Kiedis brings his lyrics and vocals in tip top form, varying from rap to wacked out funk. <BR>     My favorite's are Good Time Boys with its tight bass line, good vocals, aggressive drumming, and virtuosic guitar work. The Stevie Wonder cover Higher Ground is breakneck from start to finish with slap bass intro from Flea, guitar solo, and great sped up ending. The tribute to Hillel Slovak Knoc Me Down with a more melodic progression and Anthony shines throughout. Stone Cold Bush with a vicious bass line and bass solo, funky guitar intro and screeching solo, the lyrics shine as well. Sexy Mexican Maid is also a standout track with its laid back groove, playful guitar backing Anthony's sensual lyrics, and great guitar break. This album proves that you cant fake the funk and is a great display of the Pepper's earlier work.

B000002UW1|4.0|Considering that this was R.E.M.'s strongest collection of songs since their debut, there's a strange sense of uncertainty about the whole project.<br />You listen to the first four cuts and think &quot;Aha, another political statement from the band that brought you Lifes Rich Pageant the previous year.&quot;  Taken together, &quot;Finest Worksong,&quot; &quot;Welcome to the Occupation,&quot; &quot;Exhuming McCarthy&quot; and &quot;Disturbance at the Heron House&quot; sound very much like a sort of State of the Union address.  In each cut you get a different take on America - the dignity of its workers, the evils of its interference overseas, its historical insistence on conformity and its domestic paranoia.  &quot;McCarthy&quot; has a few awkward moments, but overall the music displays this band's usual mastery of style and technique; these songs move.  Then there's a cover version of Pylon's &quot;Strange&quot; and the whole thing breaks apart.<br />I can't help thinking that the interruption is deliberate.  R.E.M. had played plenty of covers before, and even recorded a few, but this was almost the first time they put one on a regular album release, and it's about as close to punk as they had come.  (There was &quot;Superman&quot; the previous year, but that one came at the end of the collection rather than the middle, and it was an obvious throwaway.)  &quot;Strange&quot; is like a signal to the listener, saying &quot;Whatever you think you've been hearing, that's not it.&quot;  Then the band proceeds to prove it - the rest of &quot;Document&quot; has nothing to do with political commentary.<br />&quot;The One I Love&quot; and &quot;It's the End of the World as We Know It (And I Feel Fine)&quot; both scored big on the singles charts, and I can't imagine why, since they're both among the slipperiest hits ever recorded.  They're both terrific, mind - &quot;One I Love&quot; introduces a classic R.E.M. riff and a devastating lyric, and &quot;End of the World&quot; is both nice poetry and enormous fun.  But the first of these songs doesn't mean what you think it does, and the second doesn't really seem to mean anything at all.  Why in the world did the audience take to them so strongly?  (I know, I know, they have good beats and you can dance to them, but still...)<br />The next two numbers are more R.E.M. American grotesquerie a la &quot;Fables of the Reconstruction&quot; - &quot;Fireplace&quot; is a pounding rock waltz about preparations for a hoedown that turn destructive and &quot;Lightnin' Hopkins&quot; is a vicious bluesy stomp that has about as much to do with the old bluesman of the title as the Ramones do (which may be more than I think, actually).  And then &quot;Document&quot; closes out with a couple of straight-ahead surrealist nightmares, &quot;King of Birds&quot; and &quot;Odd Fellows Local 151,&quot; with music straight out of a Ken Kesey Acid Test and lyrics by Salvador Dali or something.  They wouldn't have been out of place on R.E.M.'s dada debut, &quot;Murmur&quot; - the music is folksy but driven, the lyrics are confusing but significant, the vocal and playing style shouldn't work but they do.  It feels like you should be able to dismiss this stuff as self-indulgent, but you can't.  It means something, dammit.<br />Taken all together, &quot;Document&quot; is about as disorienting as a game of blind man's bluff.  It lurches from simple tunesmithing to scorching rock to something unidentifiable that drifts right through your head and back out into the sky.  And here's a thought - in 1987, R.E.M. faced a number of important decisions, like what record company to sign with and whether to tour Europe.  In short, they were getting famous, and I wonder if &quot;Document&quot; is the sound of a band trying to figure out whether to give its fans some good old-fashioned pop or stick with its twisted art-house roots.<br />Now, that's the kind of struggle can result in great music, when it doesn't produce a nervous breakdown instead.  Fortunately, by the time R.E.M. had to face this pressure, they had been playing together for going on ten years and evidently trusted each other.  So they could look outward and inward both at once, knowing that they had each other's backs.  Every time Peter Buck bangs out a chord, or Bill Berry and Mike Mills trade backing vocal lines, or Michael Stipe hollers &quot;Listen to me!&quot;, you can hear the band's defiance and excitement in the face of the world's demands.<br />&quot;Document&quot; is a summing up of R.E.M.'s career to that point, an important step to take before any giant leap.  They may have felt fragmented, pulled in different directions, like that glass sculptor on the cover whose body is shattered in a million pieces by his materials, but there's no doubt that they were still in control of each piece.  The following year they signed with Warner Brothers and handed in a collection of, as they said, &quot;stupid pop songs.&quot;  They'd earned the right.<br />Benshlomo says, The past is a springboard from which to jump, eyes shut, into the future.kdown instead.  Fortunately, by the time R.E.M. had to face this pressure, they had been playing together for going on ten years and evidently trusted each other.  So they could look outward and inward both at once, knowing that they had each other's backs.  Every time Peter Buck bangs out a chord, or Bill Berry and Mike Mills trade backing vocal lines, or Michael Stipe hollers &quot;Listen to me!&quot;, you can hear the band's defiance and excitement in the face of the world's demands.<br />&quot;Document&quot; is a summing up of R.E.M.'s career to that point, an important step to take before any giant leap. B00004WGY9|4.0|I owned this album in vinyl, wore the grooves out, couldn't decipher any of the lyrics but didn't care, lost it in a cross country move, and have been craving it ever since.  <br />The CD repackage includes several wonderful photos; quite a switch from the LP, which, consistent with the universal soul rebel theme,  did not depict the musicians.  It includes lyrics, which are also rather wonderful, and make all the great songs sound new again.  Finally, we get liner notes from Kevin Archer, which are informative of the band's processes, if a bit weak as to the source of inspiration.  For after all, even if the band did set out to pay homage to a certain neglected corner of soul music, what resulted was a unique and delightful pop artifact, full of witty and modern songwriting, and vocalizing that no one has dared before or since.  The horns blast away in all their retro glory, while Rowlands weaves more literary figures into his lyrics than Lloyd Cole and Morrissey combined! <br />There's an ambience here that isn't present in any other &quot;rock&quot; recording I know, with the possible exception of the Flamin' Groovies' &quot;Shake Some Action&quot;  In both records, the band members subordinate themselves so completely to the channeling of the sacred text, that authorship almost ceases to matter.  But unlike the Groovies, who had several recordings under their belts, this was a debut album, and the band, for all we knew, could have been visitors from another (very cool) planet. <br />Four stars only because there isn't more of it.

She's not doing too good trying to cut-back her spendings, but can't seem to find a way to make money.  With some comedy, heart*brakes, and falling into love. . . this book has caught the attention and affection of mine and others. Will it catch yours?
B00008OLYN|5.0|I've heard 'Damnation'  being called folk metal, progressive rock, psychaedelic rock a la the 70's, and a few other labels that don't do Opeth's latest release a bit of justice.  The first word that comes to mind when listening to Damnation is 'beautiful'.  If sound is nothing more than the arrangement of sound waves into patterns that create harmonies which are pleasing to the ear, then Opeth has succeeded in mastering the art of creating beautiful sounds.  A complete break from Opeth's previous releases, Damnation features little distorted guitar and no growling death metal vocals.  The vocals always carry a harmony that is well thought out and fits perfectly with the guitar work.  No instrument dominates the recording and the atmosphere created by the haunting subtlety of each song's melody combined with the gloomy art work and title of 'damnantion' makes this cd a near-perfect listening experience.  Damnantion was recorded at the same session as Deliverance, but I feel that Damnantion is the true jewel that arose from the recording session.  The theme of the cd seems to be loss, as in the loss of a loved one, but the theme of death never seems to leave the picture with Opeth as is seen in many of their previous releases.  The only part of the cd that I will dare to criticize is the drum sound.  The actual performance on the drums is excellent and demonstrates Opeth's drummer's ability to switch between blazingly fast metal drumming to calm percussion that sits in the background of the music.  However, the drum sound leaves something to be desired.  The toms do not have the sort of sound I enjoy and nor does the snare.  drums are not only a beat keeping insturment, but also an insturment that produces a tone through resonance of the drum skins, and the drum tone on Damnantion sounds more like pieces of plastic than anyhting else.  I was able to move past this 'problem' and it bothers me no longer.  If anyhting, I was simply searching for some flaw in this cd which seems about a perfect as one can imagine.  If you are expecting fast, thrashy metal with hints of folk-like melody that can be heard in Opeth's previous releases, do not be disappointed when you hear no such genre of music.  Damnation might be calssified as acoustic rock/metal/progressive/whatever you want to call it, but I think that the only worthy way to classify 'Damnantion' is by using the word 'beautiful'.
B00005NGZX|5.0|Perhaps this album leaves me so speechless, that I hold not many words to describe it.<BR>Or perhaps there is simply so much going on, it blows my mind.<BR>Never-the-less, on I try...<br />This is perhaps my favorite CD. It has to be heard...<br />Choosing one word to describe this CD would result in a brawl between 'Amazing' and 'Brilliant'...and 'Mindbending' would try it's damndest to convince them it is the right choice, by professing it is just one word.<br />And Just as the Album is, the song 'Jane Doe' is epic in somany different ways...<BR>It may take a few listens to appreciate this CD as something besides just 'noise,' if you aren't prepared for what it contains...

However from a purist standpoint, the FOTR stays much more true to the book. <br />I look forward to the extended version and hope to see additional footage that moves the movie back towards the book rather than futher away.  This movie receives 3 stars for great action, special effects and a good attempt at re-creating Middle Earth.  It loses two stars for unacceptible deviations from the book.

Not the type of album you'd pop in your discman and walk around with but a nice album to just put on and get absorbed into. Well worth many listens.
B00007KWHP|5.0|In an earlier review, I urged Yes fans to buy the Japanese Mini-Sleeve version of this classic album, but with Rhino's release of Fragile, I recant that earlier review and say that this reissue of Fragile is the one to buy.<br />First of all, the sound is excellent, clear, clean, and deep. I can now hear everything in a complex Yes song such as Heart of the Sunrise. Even Rick Wakeman's semi-comatose contribution &quot;Cans and Brahms&quot; has some life in it.<br />The packaging surpasses the orginal gatefold. In this triple gatefold, all original artwork and album inserts are present, printed well, and despite their minature size, almost as good as the originals.  There are additional photographs from the time of the album which deepen the ambience of the era.<br />Included in the booklet is an essay by Yes fan Bill Martin who wrote a book on Yes and notes for the In A Word Package which gives his take on the music in the album and the evolution of the band. Whether or not you agree with Martin, he's knowlegable about the history of Yes, although his musical terminology is not particularly good.<br />The bonus tracks are &quot;America&quot; which is a Yes classic cover of a Paul Simon tune, one of the last they would commit to record, and a rough mix of &quot;Roundabout&quot; which adds little to the CD, but doesn't detract from it either.<br />The four Yes songs on this Album are certainly among the best the band produced, and, at least to me, The Heart of the Sunrise, is the best song in the Yes canon.  Written to emulate King Crimson's &quot;21st Century Schziod Man,&quot; Yes goes the classic one better, producing not a dystopic scream, but a storm, a calm, a meditation, a peace.  Shifting moods, arrangements, all the things Yes would do so well for the next few years are here in HOTS. Wakeman brought Yes to life even more that Steve Howe, not so much by his actual playing, but by showing Anderson how to structure work.<br />Bravo Rhino.
B00005RY7X|5.0|you gotta love this album<BR>water world to the fullest
B000092ZYX|4.0|There is always something refreshing when a new Radiohead album comes out. You can trust that in the new songs there will be interesting instrumentation, harmonies and melodies, lyrics that grab you by the balls, and enough techno-babble to keep the songs spontaneous and intriguing. \\"Hail to the Thief\\" is not missing any of these points, but there are detractors to its glory. If anything, this album is more \\"cut + paste\\" than any of their previous works. It's clear that Radiohead have defined a style for themselves now, but the songs don't seem to have that clear inspiration or heart-wrenching sadness their other albums had. Can't blame them, though. Supposedly most of this album is a reaction of the political situation of the world and the war in Iraq. The general concensus is ignorance and disshevelment. There is no glory. It's just a weird, raw time. Radiohead are taking that attitude and smushing it in our face, beating us over the head with just how stupid all this is. So, they sacrifice a couple inspiring melodies and drama, but they hit hard with social commentary.<br />\\"2+2=5\\", a 1984 reference, is nothing short of brilliance, lyrically and musically. Thom Yorke sings absently about allowing things that shouldn't be, to be (\\"January has April showers,\\" or more realistically, letting a thief keep his reign as president), and just as he realizes how wrong it is to do that, he sings, \\"...but it's too late now, BECAUSE YOU HAVEN'T BEEN PAYING ATTENTION!\\" and literally yells \\"paying attention\\" over and over. It's a great moment when the band kicks in and they rock out. They've listened to the critics who said they forgot how to rock and show em all they still got it. It's a perfect way to start the album.<br />When asked what the new album would sound like (and this is before the unauthorized advance MP3 leak), the band said it would be a mix between their new and old stuff. Like The Bends meets Amnesiac. This is incredibly true. In fact, if you listen enough, you can section out which songs sound like rejects from previous albums. Take tracks like \\"Go to Sleep\\", \\"Scatterbrain\\", and \\"I Will.\\" They are much more melodic and atmospheric in sound than most of the other songs, which is what The Bends was all about. \\"Where I End and You Begin\\", \\"Backdrifts\\", and \\"The Gloaming\\" with their open-air composition can be traced to the Kid A/Amnesiac days, and \\"Sail to the Moon\\" could easily have slipped into OK Computer without you noticing with its dreamy texture.<br />What makes this album a complete package, however, are the songs that are not linked to any past albums, and present a new, focused sound. \\"2+2=5\\" is a good example of this, but the best track to ponder is \\"There There.\\" A good choice for a first single, There is so much rhythm in this song with the excess drums, the guitars are loud and omnipresent, as is Yorke's enigmatic voice, and they all work together to make so much of a new musical direction, it's hard to put to words. Just like the other tracks, the song picks up in the middle, and goes to a great, loud climax. Other such new blends are \\"Sit Down. Stand Up\\", \\"We Suck Young Blood\\", \\"Myxomatosis\\", and \\"A Punchup at a Wedding.\\"<br />This album also closes nicely with the momentary weirdness of \\"A Wolf at the Door.\\" It was a shock when I first heard this song, because the music is so light and carefree, but the lyrics are incredibly dark. It's quite comedic as well when Yorke nearly freestyles his lines. The incongruity of it all is perfect, albeit a really weird listen the first time around.<br />It's not necessary to know of Radiohead's history before listening to this album, but it certainly does help if you have trouble stomaching it all down. It's an album that reflects musically on the band's past and shows their plan for the future while the lyrics focus on what a weirdly unstable time period the new century has become. I think the most appropriate word to describe everything about this album is \\"unstable,\\"but as weird as it sounds, there has never been more stability in their music, their words, and their grasp of where the world is right now.

B00008J4P5|4.0|I had never heard of The White Stripes before yesterday. I was listening to our local public radio station and they played &quot;Ball and Biscuit&quot; and I loved it! It had a &quot;feel&quot; to it that didn't sound like anything I had heard in a long time. So I Went out to various web music sites and listened to tracks from all of their CDs - these guys are great! They don't sound like anybody. They don't seem to be trying to be the latest Kurt Cobain grunge band (which everyone seems to want to do these days). White Stripes have their own style and sound, and it varies considerably from album to album and even from song to song. I've seen comparisons of various songs to various bands, but most are reminiscent of no one in particular. That's what I love about White Stripes - they do what they want and they play what they want and you never know what style of music they'll play on the next track or next album. The early albums sound pretty raw, but I like that - there aren't a lot of fancy studio tricks to make it sound better. &quot;Elephant&quot; sounds like the studio spent more time making it sound good and, to me, doesn't sound as raw as the earlier albums, but I think it's every bit as good as the previous albums. Its hard to say that one album is better than another - they're all great and all different.<BR>Even if you grew up on classic rock from the 70's and 80's (like me), I still think you'll like these albums.
B00009V7T2|5.0|I can see that I've already been beaten to the punch by some of the other reviewers in pointing out what an incredibly diverse and eclectically influenced record the new TMV album is, so why beat a dead horse? This is far and away, the album of the year, due to the fact that it delivers on every level. The musicianship of everyone involved on the record is top notch, from Cedric's highly evolved vocals, to Omar's frenetic 21st century guitar heroics, to the blitzkrieg drumming and percussion, to the seamless effects and interludes that sew it all together.  <br />I can gush for hours on how exciting and invigorating the sounds are on this record, but what gets me almost as pumped up is the amount of respect I have for Cedric and Omar, the At the Drive-In vets who comprise the nucleus of this group.  Less than 3 years ago, ATDI blew me away with the intensity of their live performance at many a small show in the NYC area. When they announced that they were parting ways at what seemed like the pinnacle of the band's creative career to pursue projects outside the realm of post-hardcore (or however one chooses to inadequately pigeonhole ATDI's sound), I assumed they had opted to quit while they were ahead. I would have never suspected that Omar dissolved the band in order to pursue a project that could ever top ATDI. What a ballsy move! But this album is just that. It incorporates EVERYTHING the guys did before, including hardcore intensity, emotive vocals, frenetic rhythms, and even the sampler driven effects that used to fill up the space between songs in an ATDI set, melds it into something much more, and never looks back.<br />Enough with the comparisons, though. The past is the past, and The Mars Volta are now. Listening to this record in my friend's backyard yesterday evening, for the 10th or 11th time so far, what really sent chills down my spine is how huge this album is going to be, and how many music fans are going to be floored by this that don't know it yet.To date, The Mars Volta are still an underground phenomena of sorts, and the only people eagerly anticipating this record were those who were fans of ATDI or had heard the Tremulant EP. This will all change very soon. Whether it's a good thing or not, The Mars Volta are going to make a major impact on the state of mainstream rock. This record will probably sell over a million copies, and even though record sales don't translate into musical quality in the least, they do translate into how many sets of ears an album will reach and how many lives it will influence. I can easily see De-Loused in the Comatorium being as big as alternative milestones such as Ritual de lo Habitual, Blood Sugar Sex Magik, or OK Computer. As screwed up as the music machine may be, every so often a release such as this comes along that is so undeniably extreme, refreshing, visionary, and artistically realized that it defies the forces that feed garbage like American Idol, reality TV, boy bands, and pop divas to the art-famished masses. This record is going to explode. Just you wait and see.
B00009V7T2|5.0|I'll start off by saying was a big fan of At The Drive-In's &quot;Relationship Of Command&quot;. When ATDI split into two factions, I couldn't wait to hear both groups. One one hand there was Sparta, who's &quot;Wiretap Scars&quot; was not quite as experimental as ATDI, and boasted more radio-friendly songs. The Mars Volta however, released a 3-song EP, containing 3 odd and experimental tracks. However this did not discourage me from looking forward to a full-length album from them. After seeing them open for the Chili Peppers on their North American tour, I knew these guys had some serious potential. They put on a great stage show, yet unfortunately they did not win over the crowd.<BR>Despite this, I picked up their new album as soon as I could.<BR>Simply put, this album is easily better than both &quot;Relationship of Command&quot; and &quot;Wiretap Scars&quot;. Ever song is a totally unique and an interesting musical experience in itself. The vocals are terrific, and have improved much from the days of ATDI. The guitar jams, reminiscent of Santana on tracks like &quot;Cicatriz ESP&quot; and &quot;Take the Veil Cerpin Taxt&quot; are incredible. the drumwork is superb (and is great to see live). Flea, as always, is amazing on the bass, and offers a lot of neat riffs on the album. John Frusciante's guest appearance on &quot;Cicatriz&quot; is also amazing. There's also some interesting sound effect interludes which may remind you of Pink Floyd or Edgar Winters. To put it short, this album is a modern masterpiece.<br />If you're in for a blend of classic rock like Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, and Santana, along with latin, reggae, and obvious At The Drive-in and Fugazi influences, buy this album now. You will not regret it.

B00005JLSE|4.0|Several of the user-contributed reviews for \\"Chicago\\" make it sound like the film (and the original play and earlier works they're based on) is a treatise on the virtues of sex and liquor.<br />In fact, in one way, it is. It's a commentary on how we, society, respond to celebrity and media manipulation.<br />The first time we see the lawyer, we hear him sing about how money means nothing to him (while he's being measured for custom suits, riding in expensive cars, and having beautiful women draped over him as part of the choreography for the song). Clearly, the visuals tell us, he's a manipulator.<br />Both female leads, excellently cast (although I would entertain arguments for others in the roles, these are fine examples of the craft), are similar manipulators. The brunette murders her lover and sister (who is also her partner in her stage act) and then boasts, later, that they \\"had it comin'.\\" The blond murders her lover and then, having convinced her husband to take the fall for her, sings a ballad about how faithful he is and how much she loves him - until he realizes (about verse three of the song) that she's been two-timing him and rats her out. (I took my 63-year-old mother to see this, and she started laughing at that moment.) Mid-ballad, she changes her tune (literally) and starts singing about how disloyal he is.<br />\\"Chicago\\" is not endorsing these creeps. It's telling us that we have a voyeuristic need to follow their stories, to be entertained by the media instead of being informed by it. Certainly, you cannot see \\"Chicago\\" without acknowledging some of the grime in our world, and in ourselves.<br />It's called \\"art\\".<br />The visual style of \\"Chicago\\" deliberately pulls you in, as \\"Cabaret\\" did, by putting [nearly] all the numbers into a night-club setting so that people don't just spontaneously break into song. (That's one the big complaints about old-time musicals that I hear, and Chicago/Cabaret can't be accused of having nuns on hill-tops breaking into song.)<br />It is a great film, even if it's a bit uncomfortable in places. (A press conference scene feels almost as frightening as a debate in Bullworth in which the title character points out that the press is in the entertainment business.)g into song.)<br />It is a great film, even if it's a bit uncomfortable in places. (A press conference scene feels almost as frightening as a debate in Bullworth in which the title character points out that the press is in the entertainment business.)

B000002JS6|4.0|Many people consider Back in Black to be AC/DC greatest masterpiece. I beg to differ. While Back in Black is probably the finest album of the Brian Johnson era, the first 6 albums AC/DC did with Bon Scott on vocals cannot be touched by Brian Johnson. This album was released after the tragic death of Bon Scott, as sort of a tribute to him. But not a tribute in the fashion of slow, mournful, sickeningly melodramtic songs that bands seem to often do when they lose a member, but in the same hard-edged pure-rock format in which AC/DC has always lived. But you can begin to tell by listening to songs like \\"Have a Drink on Me\\" that they are honoring their late great lead singer, but in the way that made them great: hard rock. Now, on to the songs themselves.<br />Hells Bells: Slowish by AC/DC standards, but still a decent hard rocker, and the forboding gonging of the church bell at the beginning is an excellent touch, 4/5<br />Shoot to Thrill: Typical rocker in AC/DC's style, a song that a number of later Johnson-era AC/DC songs would come to sound like rehashed versions of, 3.8/5<br />What Do You Do For Money Honey: This song sounds a bit like typical AC/DC rockers, with a few positive twists. Sounds a bit like the song Let's Get it Up on For Those About to Rock (We Salute You), but still fairly good, 3.5/5<br />Givin' the Dog a Bone: See review of Shoot to Thrill above, 3.7/5<br />Let Me Put My Love Into You: See review of What Do You Do For Money Honey above, 3.2/5<br />Back in Black: Title track of the album, but by no means bad. This song sounds more hip-hop influenced than any rock song I've ever heard, but in this case it's surprisingly not a bad thing. True this doesn't sound like typical AC/DC, but it is still enjoyable, 4/5<br />You Shook Me All Night Long: Even people who don't know much about AC/DC have probably heard this song at one point or another, and it, along with T.N.T., has become a kind of trademark song for AC/DC. Although I am resentful that many people would come to associate AC/DC with a post-Bon Scott song, it is undeniable that this is a well-written song, and all I can say is that it is a good thing that Malcom and Angus Young stayed with the band after Bon's death to co-write more music, because god only knows what would have happened to AC/DC without them, either, 4.7/5<br />Have a Drink on Me: Though still fairly covert in it's meanings, this is the most blatant tribute to Bon Scott on the album. Even though it is Brian Johnson on vocals, it is still an homage to Bon, and a pretty well written one, with Angus Young's riffs carrying it on, 4/5<br />Shake a Leg: Another typical-style AC/DC rocker, but with a killer guitar solo by Angus Young in the middle, 4.5/5<br />Rock and Roll Ain't Noise Pollution: Written when noise pollution was becoming an issue in the U.K. and people were trying to put more bans and restrictions on music, this is a great song, and a very decent rocker, mostly because the message to the FCC-type authorities is just \\"up yours, our music is staying the same\\", 4.4/5<br />Though many of the Bon Scott-era fans of AC/DC (including myself) don't care for Brian Johnson too much, one has to admit that he is still a good singer, and that he was probably the next-best singer to Bon Scott for AC/DC. And even if you still don't like the idea of him as singer, this album is well worth the money just for the legendary, killer riffs of Angus Young alone. If you want the best AC/DC album ever, though, get Highway to Hell.

0142004235|5.0|I've read books by Steinbeck before this one. Actually, now that I think about, I read a quite a lot by him. But none of them hit me like &quot;East of Eden.&quot; I think he was truly at his best when he decided to write &quot;East of Eden.&quot; The characters are fascinating, and the way he seems to tie several different sub-plots together is absolutely amazing. His other books like &quot;The Pearl&quot; or &quot;Of Mice and Men,&quot; showed that he was a good author. But &quot;East of Eden&quot; shows that not only is he an extraordinary writer, he has gift for portraying human relationships skillfully. Truly, his use of character interactions is astounding. And each character is wonderfully full and complete, lending a multi-faceted quality to his book.

B00008G9JO|5.0|My daughter loves the smell of farms, horses and saddles. Heavy Horses is the audio version of those smells. Put on the CD, close your eyes and enjoy a slice of the country life. From the stalking acoustics of \\"...And the Mouse Police Never Sleeps\\" (one of my favorite Tull songs), which just purrs right along, to the joyous celebration of life and love which fiddles around in the dance of \\"Acres Wild\\" this album explores all the beauty and wonder of the simple life. Late night bedtime stories of beasties and the like which roam those fields of dreams stalk the listener in \\"No Lullaby,\\" while the fable recounting the folly of the moth and the flame flutters by in the gentle acoustic setting of Moths. The shuffling gait of \\"Journeyman\\" intrudes into this world, rocking back on it's heels and kicking up a little country dust, followed quickly by the breezy \\"Rover,\\" which roams this open countryside in carefree fashion. \\"One Brown Mouse\\" is a poetic observation of mice and men and their likewise treadmill existence's, written with loving tribute to it's inspiration. Dramatically raising its head in epic proportions, the records namesake is a beast unto itself. \\"Heavy Horses\\" is not only the standout track on the record, it is a Jethro Tull classic and rightly so. The song plows into the very soul that lives within any resistance against the inevitable changes of an ever-changing world, but whose values and truths refuse to die. I see the song as a kind of an analogy of Punk and Disco verses the old classic Rock. Music was changing for the worst at the time, but Jethro Tull remained clinging stubbornly (thankfully) to the stuff that really mattered: great music over poor trends. Weathering the storm of Disco and Punk to find a better day on the other side might also be seen in what was the closing song on the record: \\"Weathercock\\" (another favorite of mine). This song is redone quite well on the more recent Jethro Tull Christmas Album. Both versions are great but I actually prefer the more recent version somewhat. However they are both excellent. The bonus track is \\"Broadford Bazaar\\" which is a good song but is also available on the Nightcap CD. Still it fits in well enough here. There's a bit more sparkle in the acoustics on this new remaster making it worth owning even if you have the old one. Saddle up and take a ride and this disc will take you places you've only read about in the farmer's almanac.

From dancehall, to standard R&amp;B, the girl can do it all.  A Gospel or Latin influenced song would have really capped the set of nicely, but there is still a good mixture here.<br />Vocally, she's never sounded better than on &quot;Be With You&quot; &quot;Yes&quot; and &quot;The Closer I Get To You&quot; with Luther Vandross.  For someone of her age (21) to be able to hold her own with Luther is no small achievement.  And she wrote most of the material here, which is also quite an accomplishment.<br />In short, this is a great debut from a promising young singer.  I think she's miles ahead of most of her peers.  She has the voice, the songwriting skills, and incredible stage presence/ command.  Viva la diva (in-training)!

B00005JLYU|4.0|If you saw the first Charlie's Angels movie then you know what to expect here. It follows our scantily-clad heroes through another outlandish big-budget adventure that takes them from Northern Mongolia to Hollywood and many places in between. But it is undeniably fun and a great action movie.<br />Don't try and make sense of the story; the suspension of disbelief required to follow this movie is astronomical, and the stunts and action sequences are beyond ridiculous, but if you're prepared to let go and immerse yourself in this audio-visual feast then you're guaranteed to have some fun.<br />Cameron Diaz, Lucy Liu and Drew Barrymore shine as the title characters, they offer good performances without ever taking themselves too seriously, much like the movie itself. Demi Moore plays Madison Lee, the movie's villain, who was once a Charlie's Angel herself before she decided to quit and work for herself. Her performance is disappointing; whenever she's on screen there's a sense of \\"look at me, I'm making a comeback\\", but her role is shallow anyway so it isn't all her fault. Justin Theroux gives a delicious performance as an Irish mobster, and it's nice to see that Robert Patrick, who has fun with his double-crossing role, is getting noticed by Hollywood.<br />There are lots of celebrity cameo roles to be found in this movie, most of which work well, such as Bruce Willis, and a couple which fall flat, such as pop star Pink. I was pleasantly surprised to see comic legend John Cleese playing Lucy Liu's father, although sadly he is given little room for any comedy and is present only as a novelty. Bernie Mac is hilarious as Bosley, the girls' link with the mysterious millionaire Charlie.<br />This sequel has a more complex plot structure than its predecessor, which serves it well. It also tries to add some emotional depth by taking Drew Barrymore's character on a difficult personal journey, but whenever it does this the movie falls flat and feels totally forced, such as when Drew trudges alone into a Mexican bar for no apparent reason other than to show one of the original Charlie's Angels TV show actresses (and I'll leave you guessing which one) in a silly cameo role, by far the movie's weakest moment.<br />Even though it's basically the same as the first film, it's very hard not to like this film. A brainless summer blockbuster to be sure, but well worth seeing. 0345440900|2.0|Secrets of the Baby Whisperer is an okay read.  It presents the &quot;eat, wake, sleep&quot; routine that many people use (i.e., a baby eats, then has some awake time, and then sleeps -- instead of the baby relying on the eating to fall asleep).  And it explains how to watch for a baby's signs of sleepiness.  For these general discussions, this book is okay.  So read it if a friend gives it to you, but I wouldn't recommend buying it.<br />I find it ironic that a book which seems to promote positive interaction between parent and child in fact does the exact opposite.  Instead of promoting connecting, usually accomplished by snuggling and soothing a newborn, Hogg presents a very austere approach.  She explains that most &quot;bad habits&quot; are caused by parents rocking or swaying their children to sleep, allowing a baby to fall asleep on a parent's chest, and other things that most parents do with a newborn.  Her approach is for a baby, even at one day old, to learn to fall asleep unassisted, motionless, in his own crib.  Now, I certainly agree with the importance of a baby learning to fall asleep unassisted and developing healthy sleep habits (I highly recommend Healthy Sleep Habits, Happy Child), but most experts explain that a newborn under 6-8 weeks old doesn't have the ability to do so.  A newborn a few days or weeks old wants to be cuddled, to feel warm and safe against a parent's chest, to hear his mother's heartbeat, and to feel the rhythmic movements he became used to inside the womb.  I simply don't understand how it helps to &quot;calm, connect, and to communicate with your baby&quot; by not cuddling, rocking, or even holding your baby.  Especially for the first few weeks, after that it's important to promote some independence, but not before it's time.<br />So read the book if you have it, but do not expect it to be a manual on baby's behavior or sleep.  Instead, buy a book written by a doctor, a sleep expert.

B00002Z88D|5.0|The greatest live album of all time was recorded in April 1999 by Lars Ulrich, Jason Newstead, Kirk Hammett and James Hetfield, aka Metallica, at the Berkley Community Theatre in California, and it is called S &amp; M. Any true music fan must have this collection in their collection. It surpasses the live greats like 'Stand by your van' by Sublime and Queen 'Live at Wembley '86'. In this album the afformentioned Metallica strike a collaboration with the San Fransisco symphony orchestra, under the conduction of Michael Kamen and blast out some of there most famous songs like 'Enter Sandman' from the black album and 'Master Of Puppets' for the eponomous album.<br />One must appreciate the juxtposition of the Orchestra the crowd and the greatest rock band ever. This is particularly apparent in three of the songs. On the first cd 'The Memory Remains' incorporates the three groups that night, particularly during the piece which Marien Faithfull sings on 'Reload'. The crowd sing her piece which is very powerful. 'One' is my second favourite track with the Orchestra providing the backdrop to this classic track.<br />Finally 'Nothing Else Matters', the introductory track to CD 2, is my favourite track. With Hetfield on the acoustic guitar and Hammett and Newstead on guitar,this soft track is a powerful ballad which is a favourite to many. The true Metallica shines through here as it is clear that they can sing in many different genres thus proving that they are indeed the greatest ever rock band. METALLICA FOREVER !
B00005J6SZ|5.0|When I cast my mind back to 1984, I was 12 years old and in my first year of high school. Music had become the major focus of my life (like most teenagers), and one of my biggest highlights from 1984, aside from starting high school, was receiving the Like A Virgin album on vinyl as a Christmas present.<br />Prior to the release of Like A Virgin, her music career had been somewhat sketchy with the sleeper hit that was her first album. When the video for Like A Virgin debuted on the TV music shows with Madonna cavorting on a gondolier through the canals of Venice, it cemented her position as a major hit in the pop market. It also made us teens all the more eager for Madonna.<br />Like A Virgin, produced by Nile Rodgers, is certainly her most dated album musically. You can tell it was produced in the mid 80's with the characteristic drum machine and synthetic hand claps ubiquitously present throughout. This is not a bad thing though - the music is very tight and fresh sounding, and it was a huge commercial success.<br />The first track 'Material Girl', was the second single and another huge hit - due in part I'm sure to the very clever video with Madonna mimicking Marilyn Monroe from 'Diamonds are a girls best friend'. 'Angel' and 'Over and over' and 'Dress you up' could be described as electronica of the day, but it is the ballads where Madonna shines. 'Love don't live here anymore', one of the very few covers Madonna has done, shines not only musically but as a showcase for Madonna's burgeoning vocal talents. 'Shoobedoo', another ballad, is just as beautiful with Madonna singing about a subject close to her heart - a love gone sour. <br />'Pretender' and 'Stay', two excellent 80's sounding pop songs, finish off the original album.<BR>The two original remixes for 'Like a virgin' and 'Material girl' are added as a bonus on this release. Great for nostalgia as extended remixes in those days were a lot different to the remixes of today.<br />For fans who purchased the vinyl the first time around this is a great CD to get to complete your Madonna CD collection, especially as the music has been remastered and has never sounded better. For recent fans who may not have heard this album, it is an excellent purchase where you get to experience a part of history when Madonna's star really started to shine.
B00009V7T2|5.0|This is the best alternative album, in my opinion, that this year will produce, and I don't mean the faux &quot;alternative&quot; which stands for bands who sound exactly alike. This is true alternative music that is different from anything that has been made in recent years. The Mars Volta don't sound like anyone else. With that said, this album is a definitive musical statement. There is so much going on in this album that it's hard to believe. This is one of those records that just makes you feel so small when you listen to it, and that's a blessing. Do yourself a favor and buy this album. It just might change your perspective on a lot of things.

0375823360|1.0|Philip Pullman pretends to write fantasy, but rather uses fantasy as a platform to denounce God and present a reversed spiritual world.  Witches and the rebel angels fight on the side of good, and God and the psalm singing angels are considered evil.  One example, towards the end of the third book, is when the girl Mary describes an angel she met... \\"Her name was Xaphania.  She told me many things... She said that all the history of human life has been a struggle between wisdom and stupididty.  She and the rebel angels, the followers of wisdom have always tried to open minds; the Authority (God Almighty) and his churches have always tried to keep them closed.  She gave me many examples from my world.\\"  The Authority dies in the third book and is replaced by Enoch from the Bible.  Pullman finishes the book by encouraging people to build the Republic of Heaven since there will never be a Kingdom of Heaven. The most frustrating thing about these three books is that the reader doesn't know for sure who is bad and who is good until the third book.  As a teacher, I was reluctant to recommend the first book in the series to my students because I wasn't sure what the author was really trying to say.  By the second book, I was pretty concerned about the content but decided to wait until the third book to make a judgement.  The third book confirmed my concerns, and was disheartening to read.  I finished it, just to make absolutely sure that there wasn't a redeeming ending.  On the contrary, the book ends with the two emerging pubescent children falling in love and being intertwined in each others arms then parting for life.  Yuck!

The scene where Tony takes the reigns from Lopez is amazing. Him sitting there with his one arm in a sling clutching a gun with his other arm is great filmmaking. Tony ends up becoming the top drug lord of Miami's streets when he teams with Sosa. The relationship goes bad when Tony botches up a job Sosa gave him to do. This all leads to the climax which is one of the greatest and bloodiest scenes in movie history. It also ranks up there with some of the great endings in movie history like Se7en for example. B000089RVX|5.0|As one of the few CDs I felt compelled to actually go out and buy this year, I have to say that Evanescence's Fallen shows a promise I haven't seen the likes of since Linkin Park. And by powerhouse, I don't mean Celine Dion -- I mean Tori Amos. This is a voice that will catch you as you listen and will stay with you long after the album is over. Fallen features mostly dark and brooding rock-pop (yes, this is pop-influenced) songs, although, rest assured, it's much harder than any of Michelle Branch's brand of syrupy rock-pop. <br />Songs that stood out (And I'm saying these from memory, so they really are the stand-outs):<br />Going Under: An ear-catching opening.. Although I still think this track had religious influences, it wouldn't matter anyway. My Immortal is a mediocre song.. not cuz it wasn't well-written -- it was -- but it just never stays in my mind. Hello, however, is an imaginative and wrenching confession. Beautiful piano accompaniment to Amy's bare voice. 5/5 <br />--These were just a few of my favorite songs off the album. However, my total score for the album overall would probably be more like 4&amp;1/2 .. But I rounded up. They deserve the extra credit because we'll definitely be seeing more great albums from Evanescence in the future.

B000094A6A|4.0|First of all, a banana is not a vegetable.  A vegetable is a usually herbaceous plant (such as the cabbage, bean, or potato), which is grown for an edible part that can be eaten as part of a meal.  In contrast, a banana is an elongated usually tapering tropical fruit with soft pulpy flesh enclosed in a soft and usually yellow rind.<br />Second of all, the myth of Romulus and Remus is a Roman legend and not a Greek story.  Seduced by the god Mars (not Ares), the Vestal Virgin Rhea Silvia bore twin sons, Romulus and Remus.  Left to die in a basket on the river Tiber by her wicked uncle Amulius, the babes washed up on shore and were nursed by a she-wolf and fed bits of food by a bird until they were found and raised by a shepherd.  Growing to manhood they discovered their true identities and eventually founded the city of Rome, over the dead body of Remus.<br />When a film like &quot;Old School,&quot; which takes place across the street from a college campus, gets the facts wrong it certainly takes away from your enjoyment of the comedy.  Maybe when Will Ferrell's Frank is streaking down the street he is doing that wrong as well.  Maybe Vince Vaughn's Beanie does not give you the keys to Speaker City if he cannot beat a competitor's deal.  Maybe Luke Wilson's Mitch does remember what happened when he woke up in bed with an under aged coed.<br />&quot;Old School&quot; is about the aforementioned trio of friends who are disenchanted with becoming adults in the real world and who end up turning the house Mitch is renting into a college fraternity so that he can stay there.  That particular situation is contrived, to say the least, but then it ends up being pretty clear that the point of this film is to put three thirtysomething guys in situations that borrow from &quot;Animal House&quot; and pretty much every other party animal college film you have seen.<br />Ironically, given that this is the &quot;unrated edition,&quot; which means they throw everything back into the movie except a handful of deleted scenes, the storyline of &quot;Old School&quot; ends up seeming like scenes have been cut.  The relationship between Mitch and Nicole (Ellen Pompeo) hits a couple of stereotypical snags and they end up getting resolved off screen.  However, the biggest offense of this film is that when it comes time for the frat boys to take on the evil, wicked, bad, mean, and nasty Dean Pritchard (Jeremy Piven), the film fails to come up with anything that is either particulary memorable or especially funny.  Instead of having a climax, this film just sort of peters out at the end.<br />Yes, there are some big laughs, such as when we learn a new use for asphalt bricks, but the film is mostly Vaughn and Ferrell stealing scenes from Wilson, who really does not have a whole lot to do here.  The extras include the previously mentioned deleted scenes, some outtakes and bloopers, and a less than steller parody of &quot;Inside the Actor's Studio&quot; (Ferrell does double-duty but the other two stars and writer-director Todd Phillips (&quot;Frat House,&quot; &quot;Road Trip&quot;) look lost during the proceedings.  Certainly there are enough laughs to justify watching the film once.to the movie except a handful of deleted scenes, the storyline of &quot;Old School&quot; ends up seeming like scenes have been cut.  The relationship between Mitch and Nicole (Ellen Pompeo) hits a couple of stereotypical snags and they end up getting resolved off screen. Madonna?...I'm not saying that this band [is terrible] I'm stating my opinion that I don't like them and I'm sick of people praising then for making something that they ripped off of many respectable artists. If you like this album, fine, but I suggest you do yourself a favor and check out the roots of this music, you might actually enjoy it. And if you didn't so be it. It can't hurt to try.
B00004XONN|5.0|Although this cd is outshined in popularity by &quot;OK computer,&quot; and is known as just another chapter in the experimental days of radiohead, but that doesn't take away the fact that this IS radiohead's best album. Song after song of brilliantly written, perfectly unified music, &quot;kid a&quot; raises the bar on rock music. Every song on the album is some how correllated with the next, and still each song has its own feel. This is radiohead's &quot;Darkside of the Moon.&quot; Some radiohead fans steer clear of this album because it's &quot;wierd&quot; or whatever. Radiohead was trying something new, that deserves the fan's respect, and it deserves a listen from there mainstream rock fans. But simply because they were trying something new is not what makes this cd great, it is the songwriting, the creativity, and the originality that makes &quot;kid A&quot; radiohead's best.

B000002UAO|5.0|I think some people need to be \\"reminded\\" just how TRULY GREAT The Beatles were and still are? So before I say anything about how MAGNIFICENT Rubber Soul is, I'd like to say a few other things first. In the history of recorded music, there are The Beatles, and then there's everybody else! In fact, in the history of music there is only ONE other person who belongs \\"on the same stage,\\" and that person would be Beethoven. What do The Beatles and Beethoven have in common, that elevates them SO FAR above anybody else? They were both so good, that by merely playing their OWN music, they wrested artistic control from the hands of somebody else, and put it into the hands of the individual artist! In a productive millenia, \\"a force\\" like either The Beatles or Beethoven comes along only four or five times; and I'm talking about \\"forces\\" such as Alexander the Great! If you gave me The Beatles and Beethoven at their creative peaks, and someone took everybody else, well, MY TEAM would WIN every time; because no matter what the \\"other guys\\" came up with, if The Beatles couldn't \\"handle it,\\" then Mr. Beethoven SURE could! After The Beatles got going, then virtually EVERYBODY else was covering Beatles songs, however, they were doing NOTHING but their OWN material. <br />In 1968, The Beatles were singing about how \\"nice\\" it was to be \\"back\\" in the Soviet Union, and NOBODY said a thing; instead people just clapped and sang along! We were at the height of The Cold War, America was involved in a very unpopular confict in Vietnam, not to mention all of the civil unrest going on, but in spite of all that, a musical group released a song called \\"Back in the USSR,\\" yet NOBODY questioned if it was worthy for mass consumption? Yeah, ONLY BECAUSE The Beatles did it, and by then they'd shown THE WORLD SO MUCH, that they didn't have to prove a thing to anyone, anywhere! Oh, that was nothing, because they'd already conquered America, and they're the only one's to EVER do that; so are people \\"getting the picture\\" as to just how GREAT of a \\"force\\" The Beatles were? Also, they \\"managed\\" to PERFORM all these feats under the most INTENSE PRESSURE, that ANYBODY has ever seen, yet they didn't miss a beat! No, \\"these guys\\" kept evolving until THEY'D had enough, and after the Let it Be \\"session,\\" even George Martin thought it was over, but THEY didn't want it to end like that, so Paul called George Martin up and said, \\"WE'D like to do another!\\" Even after all that George Martin had seen them accomplish, he wasn't really sure if he or THEY were up to it? Paul said, \\"George, WE'RE SURE, WE'RE going to do one more, WE'RE going to keep this one between just you and us like usual, and things will be okay.\\" Then in spite of ALL of the distractions, turmoil, and tension, they still \\"managed\\" to turn out Abbey Road; then THEY decided it was time to take a break! <br />I'm just going to say that Rubber Soul in one of The Beatles best and most accomplished records; however, that speaks for itself! I was a very young child when they did their last show in the U.S., I'm quite thankful that I was around to see it, because if I hadn't, then perhaps I wouldn't have thought it was possible that just a few very decent and very talented people could change things for the better, by staying focused, behaving properly, and doing something extremly well? On some days, with all of the absolute nonsense and other really bad things going on in the world, well, I NEED to throw on something like Rubber Soul, in order to remind myself that something AS GREAT as The Beatles actually existed! I can understand if The Beatles aren't somebody's favorite or if they aren't their \\"cup of tea,\\" but to not respect all of their achievements, as well as how they did it, well, that I CANNOT understand! Their work belongs up with the stars, and seriously, their \\"work\\" is so good that it shouldn't even be rated by stars or anything else, because it has and will withstand the test of time; just like the \\"work\\" of Mr. Beethoven's has! Yeah, I'll take The Beatles and Beethoven, and MY TEAM would always win, in fact, do it as well as they both did, then people CAN'T stop you even if they wanted to; but what kind of person would want to? They don't come around very often, once in a lifetime if you're fortunate, and GREATNESS like The Beatles is about as GREAT as it gets!
